All they do is lay around their house and their parents don't even yell at them.

reviews.review_title: A great start from one of Amercia's best directors
reviews.content: Clerks has to be one of the best starts from a director who has never made a bad movie. Sure Clerks is in black and whitw but it's hialrous. Look for the first apperance by Jay and Silent Bob in this classic humourous flick.

reviews.review_title: Which did you like better? "Jedi" or "The Empire Strikes Back"?
reviews.content: Before Jersey Girl and the short run animated version of Clerks, Kevin Smith was aspiring to be a director. He had a vision of a story about two average Joes that work at a convenience store and video store in New Jersey. With $27,000 on his credit card, he forged ahead and produced one of the funniest films in cinematic history.None other than Kevin Smith could give us the story of Randall and Dante and their social commentary on everything from gatherings to Star Wars. Speaking to the nerd in all of us, these two characters embody the brilliance of the minimum-wage worker. The over educated, yet heavily under paid. They embody the workers that think that their jobs wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the customers. Like other Smith films, there is a portion of this film that will speak to anyone that has ever worked in the Customer Service field. While this is no Office Space, it does realistically create the lazy, film watching geek in all of us.The best part about this film is the words that Smith wrote that go into the mouths of Dante and Randall. Without these intelligent 'quips', this may not have been the film that it is today. I loved listening to everything that these two 'heroes' had to say. I also love repeating the lines to friends as we pass each other on the streets headed to our respective jobs (yes, I am one of those guys). In my eyes, this film represents the epitome of the 'cult' classic. Clerks, for lack of a better description, is a social commentary on our country, and everyone should enjoy the fruits of our Gods, Randall and Dante.Grade: ***** out of *****

It's hard not to admire a laugh-out-loud comedy that was produced on a micro-budget and has more intelligence than films that costed ten times more to make.  Kevin Smith makes an impressive debut with this wacky comedy that sticks out in people's minds and received a good cult following probably because it was...well...different.  It was original!  And though the humor is sometimes vulgar and the profanity is excessive at times, it's handled in such a smart, disciplined fashion.  Most comedy writers nowadays put vulgar material on screen and assume the audience will laugh just because it's vulgar!  It's not handled with any sense of structure.  The jokes in this movie (the confession Caitlin makes to Dante is a prime example) are handled with great structure.  Smith knows HOW to deliver a joke.One flaw that I found in this movie and Smith's upcoming movies is his use of dialogue.  Smith can definitely write great original dialogue.  But sometimes he embraces that gift a little too much.  The dialogue often works and sparks big-time laughs; other times it just doesn't flow and sounds more written than spoken.  I also thought he could've made the plot a little less implausible.  There are scenes in this movie that are based too much on coincidence, and it ruins the film's rhythm, giving it a bit of a forced plot-driven feel.  And of course some scenes are just so out of the ordinary that you just stare in awe.  The guy who checks the quality of every egg? It turns out he has a disorder only rampant among guidance counselors, because their jobs are so pathetic.  There has to be a truth to every joke, and jokes like that are just plain goofy.However, those are minor flaws, and if you consider the high-budget crap that's been thrown in our faces year by year--this movie is a masterpiece in comparison.  It's original, hilarious and smart!  How often do you get all those qualities in one comedy?So if you haven't seen "Clerks" yet...I suggest you check it out.  You'll have a ball.My score:  7 (out of 10)

Poor Dante. He's not even supposed to be here today. But on his supposed day off he has been called in to work. He's just a lowly clerk in a convenience store so you'd think Dante would be in for a very boring day. What interesting things could possibly happen in a convenience store? Well, thanks to the brilliant script from Kevin Smith we get to peek in on what has to be the most eventful day in convenience store history. On this day the Quick Stop will prove to be Dante's personal hell. And he doesn't even get the worst of it. Not by a long shot.Clerks is among the most gleefully profane films ever made and yet it manages to have great charm. You can't help but sympathize with poor Dante, even when he's acting like a bit of a cad, going behind his ever-loving and faithful girlfriend's back to try to hook up with an ex. And Dante has the perfect comic foil in Randal, who works at the video store next door. In reality Randal really doesn't work at all, he just hangs out at the Quick Stop with his best bud Dante. And the interaction between this pair is priceless, every conversation they have is pure comic gold. Randal is a guy who will do or say absolutely anything and Smith uses that to great effect. Randal goes way over the line, providing an abundance of laugh out loud moments. Did he really say that? Yeah, he did.The movie is performed by a cast of amateur, completely unpolished actors. And that proves to be a very good thing. It helps the movie feel real. There's nothing forced or fake about it. These are real people, real Jersey people with the type of edge to them you wouldn't see in most other places. Everyone in the cast, from those playing the main characters all the way down to those on the screen for mere moments playing annoying customers, is excellent. The performers may not be polished but that doesn't mean they are bad actors, quite the contrary. Jeff Anderson, playing Randal, is a standout and Brian O'Halloran is great as well in playing the put-upon Dante. Of course Dante and Randal are not the only dynamic duo in this movie. There's also Jason Mewes and Smith himself as Jay and Silent Bob adding some laughs and maybe even some wisdom. The movie crackles along with some of the wittiest dialogue ever put to film. Few movies are as quotable as this. Whether Dante and Randal are discussing their menial jobs or the destruction of the Death Star the dialogue sparkles throughout. You don't even need context. "I'm 37?" Just hearing that is enough for fans of the film to laugh and give a knowing nod. So many hilarious little moments in this movie. And some truly outrageous big moments as well including a twist of fate at the end which is wonderfully set up and pays off in rather unbelievable fashion. The movie is so rude and crude and yet it is rightfully beloved. People love this movie, these characters, this story. Absolutely brilliant stuff from Kevin Smith and his terrific cast. World, don't say New Jersey never gave you anything. Please accept this movie as our gift to you. If you don't like it I may have to go all Berserker on you.
I like the bit where they close the store and play hockey on the roof

Clerks, shot entirely in black and white, obeys the Aristotelian unities of time, place and action in the sense that it captures the lives of Dante and his friend Randall (who are two store clerks) during the duration of a single day, concerned mainly with their interactions with the store customers. The dialogue is smart, rather too smart for normal conversation. Clerks is a smart comedy, the kind that requires you to pay good attention to. Rather big words were shown against a black backdrop at regular intervals during the film. I found this a tad annoying as I didn't really know what half of these words meant.The movie showed me that handling customers is not an easy job. It's a decent low-budget film, is deserving of the cult-following that it has.

People kept telling me how great this movie is.  One even said it would be in my top 10 after I saw it.  It may be in my top 10 all-time worst films. A lousy script with few laughs.  The acting was horrible, led by the guy who played Dante.  I'm sure it happended somewhere, but cited for selling ciggarettes to a 4 year old?  Come on.

Clerks marks the "titanic" debut of writer/director Kevin Smith, whom some consider the next John Hughes.  While this statement is debatable, what is NOT debatable is the fact that Smith has turned out better quality work since this.  Hughes has not improved since Planes, Trains, and Automobiles. Clerks concerns a day-in-the-life of Dante and Randall, two rather sophisticated employees at the local Quik Stop.  What intelligent conversations they have!  The most intelligent my days at 7-11 ever got was who was dating who and whether or not the Red Sox would win the World Series.  BAH!  Smith certainly loves injecting pop culture whenever he can, whether bashing unbearably stupid movies ("Ooh! Navy SEALS!") or questioning the ethics of Star Wars in ways the George Lucas certainly never thought of.  He might not be Shakespeare and his chatter can get downright clunky, but there is no doubt that he works the ideas for all they're worth.  A lot of Randall's delivery is totally off in contrast to Dante's, maybe he should've spent less time reading porn and more time on the script.  Watch the short "The Flying Car" for a sample of what they are capable of concocting.Unfortunately, the story is a grab bag of ideas and images reminiscent of Kentucky Fried movie that make little sense in the long run.  By the time Smith actually tries telling a story, the audience doesn't care anymore because they are too engrossed in his little skits.Jay & Silent Bob are the highlight, but they don't have much to do until the end.  I consider this a waste of ideas and ability, but the narrative that Smith constructs with them makes up for that fact.  No wonder he always brings them back.On the technical level, this is NOT Terminator 2.  The camera is always dead-on and treats the topic as more of a stage play and less of a movie.  I will give bonus points to that.  The editing is decent, but many scenes lack the securing touch that hold them together with the rest of the movie.Overall, comedy fans should like it (as should anyone else who's tried working at a place like this), but sensitive reviewers should pass off since there is no topic or idea that Smith isn't willing to try.  Social satirists might also get a kick out of it.  3.5 out of 5 stars.

I have heard a lot about this film, most of it has been very positive, so I was quite keen to see what all the fuss was about. What I found was a very interesting low budget black and white film that talks a lot about relationships, human nature and all kinds of crazy stuff. I guess the film is most notable for introducing to the world the characters Jay and Silent Bob, and if you don't know who those guys are then you're probably reading the wrong review! But more of that later, here's a short plot summary before I tell you want I really think.Dante works in a convenience store. It is his day off but his boss has called him in to cover for him. The day starts normally enough, but he can't open the main shutters because someone has put gum in the locks. His girlfriend, Veronica, comes in to see him on her way to college. She thinks he could do better and tries to persuade him to join her at college. Dante is stuck in his ways and is happy to stay at the store for the time being. After she leaves, Randal arrives to open the video rental store next door. He spends most of the day closing the video store so he can go and hang out with Dante. It transpires that Dante is still holding a torch for his ex-girlfriend, Caitlin and has recently been in touch with her. When the pair, Dante and Randal that is, discover that Caitlin is engaged to be married, things get really interesting. Throw in a hockey game on the roof, a funeral, a death and the lamest fight scene I've ever seen and that about covers it.I will admit I did find the character of Randal pretty annoying although he did talk a lot of sense in the end. The performances were pretty good although not as polished as I'm used to. So honourable mentions go to; Brian O'Halloran as Dante, Jeff Anderson as Randal, Marilyn Ghigliotti as Veronica, Lisa Spoonhauer as Caitlin, Jason Mewes as Jay and Kevin Smith as Silent Bob.Although it's not the best comedy I've seen for a while, I can see the appeal of it. There are a lot of crazy characters and some pretty good one-liners that raised a laugh or two. Over all I pretty much liked this film I can't say exactly why, maybe it was Silent Bob's words of wisdom, but over all, it's recommended.My score: 6.7/10

reviews.review_title: "What the hell kind of convenience store do you run here?"
reviews.content: God, this movie is charming. You can tell from minute one what kind of low-tech entertainment you're getting into, but once the conversations start up, you're in it 'til the end; at least I am. It's easy to shrug off the performances (unpolished is putting it lightly) with dialogue this pleasing and I find myself glued to the screen as the characters exchange banter; an unlikely bromance between the line-toeing Dante and the agitating Randal."Clerks" is instantly relatable for anyone who's toiled in retail, it's pretty much emblematic of Gen Xers; right down to the somewhat anthemic "I'm not even supposed to BE here today!". As an employee, I was always Dante, and always wanted to be Randal; maybe that's the eternal conflict in every working stuff. Hell if I know. But I can tell you this is a genuinely funny movie, wildly entertaining and somehow timeless (despite the massive '90s imprint).Kevin Smith nailed it with this.

Clerks is a bold, bold movie. Kinda sad that people intelligent enough to appreciate it are driven away by the foul language and sex jokes, and the people worldly enough to understand it are driven away by the lack of action ("F***ing boring, man, it's just two guys quoting Star Wars and swearing at each other at a convenience store."). Watching the film in either of these contexts will give you the wrong impression, for what Clerks is, more than anything, is a uniquely American take on the French art film. Not an incredibly masterful art film, mind you, but the attempt to bringing something like this to an American mass audience in perfectly serious non-parody is ambitious. What people don't understand about this movie is that it isn't just a bunch of guys doing nothing and telling dirty jokes. There's a subtext to this film--not an incredibly deep subtext, and subtle enough to go under the radar of the lowest denominator (whom, sadly, this film was marketed to), but powerful and thought-provoking nonetheless. Every seemingly pointless conversation, every seemingly irrelevant reference to oral sex contributes to the sense of ennui and despair that the protagonist Dante experiences. Everything that happens to him, every person he meets, illustrates a miserable existence in which he does little but sacrifice his own needs in order to protect empty obligations to guilt-tripping, passive-aggressive people. Dante's delinquent, happy-go-lucky foil Randal, who is in the exact same situation and quite satisfied with it, the Millerian Biff to Dante's Willy (WOOOOO! OBNOXIOUS LITERARY REFERENCE AND DOUBLE ENTENDRE!), constantly reminds Dante that he has the power to leave his thankless job, that he has the power to turn his life around--a power that Dante's complacency forbids him from exercising. It is a feeling that will hit close to home for anyone who has experienced the boredom and the meaninglessness of working in a convenience store. Crude? Yes--but that's what it's like when you're spending ten hours a day bagging groceries and self-superior ass hats are giving you crap because they have higher paying jobs. This is not a film for people who believe that people in low-paying jobs are there because they belong there, it is a film against these people.The directing style borrows from New Wave auteur Jean-Luc Goddard's bag of tricks; the extremely long takes, little camera movement, black and white film stock, minimum of sets, and occasional jump cut create a feeling of ennui and despair absolutely forbidden by go-go-action-action keep-the-lowest-denominator-on-their-toes Hollywood. The sick jokes and nasty humor are more than mere character development; they build the tension of the movie and drive it along at a leisurely pace. Dialogue, not action, drives this film, and the abusively friendly relationship between Dante and Randal is one of the most interesting and genuine Hollywood friendships since Riggs and Murtaugh in Lethal Weapon--no small feat for Brian O'Holleran (Dante) and Jeff Anderson (Randal), who pull through in spades, portraying an absolutely convincing pair of convenience store workers fresh out of college. This film hits you right in the gut--it is the cold, hard reality of the American working class told in the authentically crude language of the working class, told in possibly the most pretentiously inaccessible format ever. France has always chided America for not understanding subtlety. It's a shame they were right.Four stars out of five.

When one looks at Clerks, it's pretty easy to realize that it's a bit overrated. It's not to say it is a bad movie, but considering how much respect and a cult it has created in its wake, it seems a bit too much. The film was a major hit in the '94 Sundance. I guess people were captivated that a man who worked in a convenience store was able a movie greater than most people make in the entire career.Now don't a Shakeperean story here. It tells the story of Dante Hicks (Brain O'Halloran), your everyday clerk whose brought in on his day off. Throughout the day, he and his best friend/worst enemy/co-worker Randal Graves (Jeff Anderson) several obstacles in a greatly monotonous job. This includes screwed up customers, girlfriends, and stoners Jay (Jason Mewes) and Silent Bob (Director/Writer Kevin Smith).What probably got to audience the most was the film's no-hold bars, raunchy dialog that threatened it with NC-17 rating. Kevin Smith holds no qualms in creating some of most sexual-explicit situations in film history. Many times it feels forced and over the top, usually putting me in an uncomfortable place.That being said though, Smith is able to write some amazing characters. In most days, studios and filmmakers try to usually to cram the films characters down our throats so by the end of the day, we're suppose to feel for them. Smith doesn't do that. He just lets the characters play out, putting them situations that relate to the audience. These situations include be stuck in a dead-end job, yet never having the courage to leave and start a real-life. Smith makes us feel whatever we want to feel for the characters, which they're usually soon in the positive light.The film's looks is also something to be admired. Usually, independent films pride themselves for their artistic vision. The opposite could be said for Clerks. The movie is so artistically challenged it gives it a grainy, poor look that puts the audience in a world unlike most others.While not nearly worth the years of hype, Clerks remains a wonderful and nicely done comedic-farce.

reviews.review_title: Kevin not So silent (Bob) has a lot to say
reviews.content: I have to wonder .. what is weirder. Someone who knows Kevin Smith and watches him as Silent Bob for the first time or someone who was introduced to Silent Bob first and then saw Kevin Smith ... the difference could not be bigger - especially when it comes to the talking of course.But Kevin took a back seat in his own movie and let others do the talking. Getting the idea of "I can do that" from Slackers, he went out and did what he knew best and what he had access- an advice that Robert Rodriguez gave out to young filmmakers. Although surely also to older ones - no age shaming here.That being said, almost everyone could identify with the characters here. Either because many worked in similar jobs or at least knew the enviroment - to put it mildly. Now the main focus here are the dialogs and the "jokes" sometimes just visual. The dialog though does contain a lot of vulgar language ... you may have issues with that. Because while there is no nudity to speak of, there is a lot of sex talk. Including some very graphic descriptions ... if you have issues with that, the movie will very much offend you.The target audience loved it though ... they felt represented on screen. I do not condone certain things that are being done or said here, but for the movies sake I have to admit, they work quite nicely. There is a reason the movie still holds a very special place in many peoples hearts ... and Kevin Smith is such a loveable nerd - it's almost impossible to not like this. I know though that taste differ and some will find this highly annoying - does not change the fact that this was made as good as it was possible under the conditions and the low budget.

Kevin Smith's first film, Clerks, is amazing. Only Tarantino could use profanity so poetically. The film doesn't have the best acting in the world, being that it's all of Smith's friends, but the script is written so well it doesn't matter. Smith has a long future making films. He has a very good eye and ear for comedy.

reviews.review_title: A rare really good independent movie.
reviews.content: Clerks was a very funny movie. I hate most independent movies, I don't hate Clerks by any means. The first half of Clerks is pretty good. The second half is very good. Packed with entertaining people. People in and out of the stores. Almost every joke is sex-related, but that doesn't matter. All in all it's a good movie. I give this movie *** out of ****

reviews.review_title: So this is what the fuss was about
reviews.content: Getting through the first few minutes was rough, and it only got a little better. The movie, face it, doesn't really make sense in a bad way - people's actions don't look real (people are so obviously playacting transactions at the store counter that it's not funny), things happen as obvious set-ups for jokes, and it's so haphazardly shot that you don't get any sense of the locations and where people are in them. Brian O'Halloran isn't bad at all, but the rest of the actors are terrible (no fault) and have obviously in many cases not learned their lines (no excuse). The writing is only fair at best - sometimes funny, often dull, frequently obviously "writing."It's interesting to contrast this with another zero-budget personal film, Mark Borchardt's "Coven." Borchardt has a surprisingly good visual sense and is a much more imaginative writer, but he apparently doesn't have the personal organization or support to pull off directing a feature-length film. Smith seems to have those things, and so he has a career. That's good for him, but I can't imagine taking the time to see anything else he's done.

reviews.review_title: I'm not even supposed to be here today!
reviews.content: This unusual comedy was Kevin Smith's firstborn, low-budget black and white movie that launched him as one of the wittiest screen-writers/directors of today, and the first appearance of Jay and Silent Bob, awkwardly hilarious duo that became a legend. "Required reading" for all lovers of independent film.9/10

Clerks. is the debut film from Kevin Smith, an independent film that came out of nowhere in 1994 and made Kevin Smith an icon in the indie scene. The film is shot in black and white, is very low budget and reeks of first film production values. Not that this is necessarily a bad thing.Running just over an hour and half, the story concerns two employees of a convenience and video rental store, Randal and Dante, respectively. Taking place over one day, it begins with Randal being coerced into work on his day off. What follows is less of a plot and more a series of vignettes that tell the story that unfolds. Hockey, sex, smoking, drugs, death, the doll drum of life, the predictability and annoyance of work, friendship, love, and lots and lots of cussing make for one funny movie.The humor is really what makes Clerks. work. Smith's writing is on fire, hilarious, realistic and on the nose. Some of the dialogue is destined to, and has become classic. Trying not to give anything away, remember these words (for those who have not seen this movie yet): 37 and Star Wars. The writing and humor, as mentioned is the strongest part of Clerks., so take that away and what are we left with?Super low budget, almost student film like, Clerks. actually at times feels like a student film. The acting is, not bad, but not great. The editing, pretty doldrum. In fact, the editing makes the acting seem stilted to a certain degree. The cast gives it their all, Jeff Anderson, who plays Dante, is laugh out loud funny but like the rest of the leads, he comes off as slightly amateurish. Jason Mewes (Jay) and Kevin Smith (Silent Bob) fare the best, while not Oscar worthy they are the only two that move past the 'film-school' sense of acting and possess a sense of 'skill'.Not that the rest of the acting is horrendous by any means, but what can you expect when a film is made by a few guys straight out of film school. As I said before, the editing is rather ho hum, with glaring inconsistencies, bad jump cuts and very slight issues with pacing. The film could maybe be trimmed by a few minutes, but for the life of me, thinking back on it, I can't think of what. It just seemed a tad sluggish.Another issue is Smith's directing. A word to describe the direction of Clerks. is: Static. That's right, static. What do I mean? Well, like the story, where not much is happening, so to is the direction of the film. The camera rarely moves, the people rarely move, and the action rarely moves from one location; everything is still, there is no flow, there is no sense of style, again the word to use is static. It's almost as if Smith just pointed the camera and shot, making the direction seem cold and rigid.Now don't get me wrong, I did like this movie. It was original, and funny. Very funny. I watched this for the first time two days ago (Feb. 12/2012) and enjoyed it immensely. I thought the writing was superb, and although there is not much of a story, I was compelled to the end, laughing all the way. The writing really does elevate this movie to higher place.The static direction, choppy editing and 'film-school' acting was a mild deterrent, as was the ever so slightly sluggish pace. But Clerks. screenplay is so good you forget about those problems for most of the film. If you want to laugh for an hour and a half, you can't go wrong with Clerks.Film Rating: 70%Breakdown (How Clerks. scored 70%):Production Design: 7 out of 10 Cinematography: 7 out of 10 Re-playability: 9 out of 10 Originality: 9 out of 10 Directing: 5 out of 10 Editing: 5 out of 10 Script: 10 out of 10 Acting: 6 out of 10 Sound: 6 out of 10 Music: 6 out of 10

Been a while since I first watched Clerks, and at least two years since last I saw it.  I can't say what it is exactly about this movie, but it had a hook that grabbed me.  It wasn't the soundtrack, the plot, the B&W aspect, or even the characters that did it.  It just grabbed a hold of me and said 'this is good'.  Looking back from now, what I can remember of it the most would be the feelings of frustration ("I'm not supposed to be here" type of frustration) that we can all relate to.It didn't suck.

reviews.review_title: Some funny scenes, but most dialogue on adolescent level
reviews.content: Note: I am over 45 years old and a female.I can see why this would be very funny to an audience of males under 26 years old. It does have humor. The script is well-written, but that doesn't mean you will enjoy it. I also only watched a half hour of the movie because I wasn't in the mood to waste my time. In my case, I have to relate to the characters in some way to enjoy a movie. These people acted very immature. I think that is the point of the movie, but I also believe that this would not appeal to most audiences over 40 years old. The movie got very good ratings, but beware, ratings are not enough. Know yourself. Evaluate the reviews ahead of time to see if you think the topic or type of characters would interest you.

This movie is full of dialogues I see that there isn't any particular story or significance for it ,if you value your time and you just trying to laugh it off ,find you another movie because this is boring except if you'd like to listen to bunch of clerks pointless parleys I wouldn't recommend it it's total waste of time in my point of view

reviews.review_title: Good but not great, but it certainly gives hope to anyone that wants to make a good yet extremely cheap film
reviews.content: Clerks is the one film that put Kevin Smith on the map--whether this is a good thing or a bad thing, that is for you to decide. With an extremely low budget and a cast of actors and actresses that for the most part had no acting experience whatsoever, it was amazing that the film was made and is as popular amongst the indie crowd as it is today. Grossing over 3 million dollars at the box office, soon it would launch a wave of lower-budget movies about people and their jobs and the lives that intertwines with it, most notably Office Space and Waiting. Unfortunately, I was unable to see what the big fuss is about with Clerks. While it is mildly entertaining, there are much better low-budget films out there with better dialogue and more humor. It's quite an achievement to get so much success when considering how little he had to work with, but aside from that it was a rather mediocre film.Dante is this low self-esteem, bitter, unappreciative clerk that has to fill in for someone else while his boss sneaks away to another state. As the day progresses, a large series of events adds and subtracts from his obviously-gloomy mood, ranging from his girlfriend's past, to his ex-girlfriend getting married, to a hockey game gone wrong, and more. Dante is joined by his sly, fast-talking Randal and outside the store is the odd yet inseparable duo Jay and Silent Bob that offers a few interesting moments. Throughout the film Dante and Randall try to figure out things that happened in the past, why they work such awful jobs, and also argue as to which Star Wars movie had the better ending.With little money and few places to film, the movie relies pretty much all on the dialogue and the interaction amongst the characters. Clerks is a mixed bag in multiple ways: the movie is a mix of comedy and a bit of drama, and also sometimes the movie is very smart and very funny, and at other times it's just a bit of a bore. Jay and Silent Bob really aren't that big of a deal in this film, especially when compared to Dogma. Dante's personality is quite annoying, he is always nagging, complaining, whining, and really doesn't give the actor much to work with. Randall on the other hand, provides the best lines, provides the best laughs, and also seems to have the most fun in the film. His moments in the video rental place where he works are priceless, as he takes no bull from the customers and just doesn't care.While the females in the film do not get much screen time, they are available for the biggest laugh and the most depressing moment. Marilyn Ghigliotti (I list this actresses' name because I was most impressed by her performance) as Veronica provides a wonderful monologue basically putting Dante in his place after discovering something that he was going to do. Meanwhile, Caitlin, Dante's ex-girlfriend winds up doing something so unexpected and off the wall; it will throw you off for quite a bit. Either way, it's a hit-or-miss movie, and this does indeed hit for some laughs and some thought-provoking scenes but then sort of misses with jokes that weren't' funny or repetitive quotes or pointless dancing.Bottom Line: Not as good as everyone makes it out to be, but it is indeed a film that gives filmmakers with no money hope that someday they'll make it big without needing a ridiculously large budget. The acting was very good for inexperienced actors, the writing was pretty clever, but there isn't much more going for it after that. Being in the quick service industry, I could relate to it a little, but at other times Clerks just sounded like a long complaint captured on film. Clerks: Not deserving of "classic" status, but a benchmark in indie film-making.7/10

reviews.review_title: Pull foot out of mouth and tail from between legs...
reviews.content: So I screwed up.As you may have noticed, there are two comments from me on this film. A bit of background may be in order.The first one was written by me immediately having followed watching the movie. Previous to that, I had seen (In order) Dogma, Mallrats and Chasing Amy. On an absolute buzz from the pure Kevin Smith wit, I plugged in the original.And was tremendously disappointed.Feeling betrayed (For no adequately good reason) I wrote an incredibly harsh review here. (You can read it at http://us.imdb.com/CommentsShow?109445-116 )Then I went to work. And boy oh boy, did I suddenly realize exactly where this film is coming from.Kevin Smith has done a wonderful, almost scarily lifelike representation of what working in any convenience industry is like. I've had customers worse than Randalls "Do you have the film from last year with the guy who was in that other film?", I've been able to see exactly what kind of brain-dead morons so many people really are. If anything, Smith is a little gentle on the people who come into the store.Many of my complaints I hold to. It's slow at times, and the words on screen at times remain mysterious and don't enhance the film.But damn it all. If you can't relate to this film, you've never worked in a burger chain, a video store, or even, yes, a convenience store. Otherwise, you _will_ relate to it.Even if it takes you two goes.

reviews.review_title: Does title dictate behaviour? This, along with many other important questions on life, are answered (somewhat) in this film!
reviews.content: One of the funniest films I've ever seen. Kevin Smith's 1994 debut is a phenomenally funny, dialogue-driven film about two friends, Dante and Randall, over one shift at a supermarket and the adjoining video-rental shop. They discuss life, Star Wars, sex, work and get in to all sorts of awkward and hilarious encounters with customers. Oh, and they also attend a wake and play a game of hockey on the roof. There is also a spot of necrophelia in there somewhere! You just don't know what is going to happen next, or what sort of lunatic is going to walk in through the door and harass Dante. "I'm not even suppose to be here today!" Becomes his mantra before long. This guy just can't catch a break, but he does himself no favours. To add torment to what was supposed to be his day off, he finds himself caught in a love-triangle between his current girlfriend and his ex. I think the performances are solid in this movie where the main winner for it is it's script and dialogue. It is relentless in it's humour and is excellent from start to finish. It caters to a certain taste, that's for sure. And people will either absolutely love it, or find it boring.

It may be hard for people to believe that I saw this when it first came out, given that I was only 10. But I did. Obviously, we'd never heard of Kevin Smith before, but he has developed quite a career since. "Clerks." of course focuses on the lives of some people working in a convenience store.It was really something seeing this movie and hearing all the stuff about sucking d**ks. It's probably the sort of movie that can only appeal to twenty-ish people, but a neat one at that. Jason Mewes and Kevin Smith also make their debuts as Jay and Silent Bob, respectively. Pretty interesting, although definitely not for everyone.

Have you ever seen a movie that you absolutely loved for just one reason. Maybe it was just one actor who did a phenomenal job, or the directing style. Clerks isn't the funniest film I've ever seen, it's not the most well made, nor the most well acted. However it does one thing so well that it made me love it, and that was the character of Dante.Dante, is the most relatable character in any movie I have ever seen, to me that is. He reminds me so much of myself, always letting people make you do things, never saying no. The speech Randal gave at the end was like he was talking directly to me, minus the stuff about Veronica. When bad things happen to him, I felt genuinely sorry for him.That is the reason I love this movie so much, because it's so relatable.There are other good things, it does have some good jokes. Although this style of comedy may not be for everyone. The characters are fun, and the dialog is fantastic, really realistic.Clerks is a movie that succeeds because of it's script. The film actually doesn't look that good. It's a movie that may not be for everyone, but I loved it, and it is my favorite Kevin Smith movie to date.

Clerks is a great way to kill 90 minutes. It's a hilarious, and very addicting movie that can be watched over and over. Kevin Smith is easily my favorite filmmaker, and I doubt that anyone will ever top him. Kevin Smith, as you may have heard, is a master with dialogue, writing some of the funniest, most insightful and quotable dialogue you'll ever hear. Made on a budget that would only allow such a thing, Clerks is barely anything more than a series of conversations.The whole movie is a day in the life of a video store clerk, and a convenience store clerk. Over the day, they discuss many things (sex), play hockey on the roof of the store, deal with, and occasionally dis the many jackass customers. One of the best bits in this film is at the beginning when a customer talks a bunch of other customers out of buying cigarettes, by showing them a blackened lung. I dare you not to laugh when his true intentions are revealed. There is a hilarious discussion about Star Wars, which proposes a question never answered in the series, and never asked in here. Some of the conversations are extremely sexual. I won't go into detail, but let me just say, you'll snicker every time you hear the number "37." The main characters are some of the best ever created. Dante is a total straight guy who just wants to be responsible. He wants to do something with his life, but completely avoids it. He's an everyman who has almost constant problems with women, and is clearly full of stuff he'd like to say to many people. But his judgment is so good, that he lies about how he really feels, hoping to avoid trouble whenever possible. The reason it often wouldn't be possible is due to the other guy, Randall, who says what's on his mind, and frequently gets Dante into trouble. He is one of the funniest characters ever created (especially the exaggerated version of him in the animated series). He mouths off to customers, abuses his authority, and constantly closes his store to talk to Dante. Strangely enough, as stupid as Randall comes off, he is actually very insightful about many things, actually more than Dante. His speech toward the end about how pointlessly pessimistic Dante is is absolutely brilliant. Dante represents who most of us are, and Randall represents the person most of us wish we had the guts to be. If it were socially acceptable, the world would be plagued with people like Randall. I'll bet even Dante has the mentality of Randall deep down. For a low budget film about people going to work and talking, these characters are very deep, and very well developed, probably among the most well developed characters ever created. That right there, is what makes Kevin Smith so brilliant. He can take no substance, and turn it into substance with his characters.Clerks is a truly outstanding, and inspirational film, that can be watched over and over, and you'll never get tired of it, as long as this kind of movie appeals to you.Clerks is rated R for Extensive Use of Extremely Explicit Sex-Related Dialogue and Strong Language. Sex: 7/10 Violence: 2/10 Swearing: 10/10 Drugs: 5/10

As someone that has worked a good bit in customer service jobs this movie is always going to be a favorite. The situations might be played up but anyone that's ever been in a retail space can tell you this level of nonsense absolutely happens. To paraphrase MIB, "The person is smart, people are stupid" and there are a lot of people in the world. What always amazes me is the simplicity of this movie. It's made on a nearly nonexistent budget with an, at the time, unheard of director and his buddies playing the parts but it's so smartly done. They was Smith uses his limitations in his favor rather than letting them impede the process. He might not have had the best actors but there's a reality to what's happening and the dialogue is on point. I have absolutely sat around in a store and had conversations with coworkers on par with the Death Star discussion.Overall, I love this movie and I do think this is one that everyone should really check out if they've missed it. As Office Space was the rallying cry film for office workers, Clerks is the unifying movie for retail personnel. It's a perfect indie movie and definitely worth the time.

reviews.review_title: Clerks defines the lowest common denominator of comedy
reviews.content: If you think that the use of the F-word for verbs, nouns, adjectives exclamations, pronouns and any other possible place it can be inserted is well written script than clerks is the movie for you. I was amazed how bad this movie was. The actors talked like they were reading from scripts and the humor was as about as low and base as humor can get. I could have written a better script when I was twelve when disgusting sex and bathroom humor was at its peak in my life. If you are going to be gross, at least be clever.Apparently, the humor in this movie is supposed to get laughs through shock. I was neither shocked or amused by the humor in this movie. It did not offend me as much as it just seemed completely brainless. Dirty jokes are always the easiest to write.

Clerks seems to stand in everyones minds as one of the best comedies of the 90's. A debut for not only Kevin Smith at director but also the View Askewniverse in films. Clerks is what got everything started for Smith and in my opinion remains as his best work of comedy to date (with Mallrats in a very close second). Just that freshness the first I saw it enters my mind every time I manage to catch Clerks on television. Clerks remains as a great comedy.Filmed in all black and white, Clerks follows the day of Dante Hicks, a clerk at a New Jersey convenience store, and his pal Randal Graves, who is the laid back clerk at the neighboring movie store. It follows mostly Dante as he worries about his relationships, confronts strange customers, and takes his job too seriously. Randal stands by as the other main character who often times convinces Dante to take chances. Randal proves to be the funnier of the two with his sick humor, laid back personality, and little care for anyone beside his close friend Dante.Brian O'Halloran makes his film debut as Dante. Brian makes Dante out to be exactly what he is suppose to be. Too uptight, always a push over, and always unsure on what to do in life with himself and his relationship. O'Halloran isn't exactly funny, he is more of the set up guy for Randal whenever he is in the scene or the bearer of the comedy from most of the characters. Needless to say he causes few laughs but his serious face is needed for the other characters to bring the comedy in scenes.Also making their film debut is Jeff Anderson as the ever hilarious and now famous, Randal Graves. Anderson portrays perfectly the typical slacker. Randal rarely cares what is going on, even when he is at his job. He watches out for Dante but rarely cares about anyone else. Anderson is hilarious as Dante just based on how relaxed he is when he says things, even the most disturbing parts he is laid back and says it as if he is constantly thinking it. Anderson is the man of many laughs in Clerks and without him as Randal, no doubt the film would have failed.Being as the film is the first for practically everyone in the cast and crew it is amazing the amateurism did not show. The camera work is steady and solid, the writing is superb, and the setting (a convenience store for 99% of the movie) is perfect. The film introduces the now famous Jay and Silent Bob who harass passer-byers and deal drugs. Most of the cast will not be recognized but they are amazing. For a film that only cost $27,000 USD to film, it goes down as an amazing comedy.The major turn off for most who do not like the film is its obscene humor and various explicit sexual references. People remember this is not a kids film, keep kids away and you'll have no problem. The comedy is not slapstick humor, it is mostly laid back humor written in such a way that a person will never see the joke coming. What long stands out in my mind as the genius of this film is Caitlin Bree and the bathroom though I won't reveal anymore. Just watch this film. You will not regret it.4.5/5 stars

reviews.review_title: Great movie, but at the same time overrated
reviews.content: I used to swear that this was one of the best movies, especially best independent film and one of the best screenplays. But after watching it many more times, it does dawn on a viewer that a lot of things are amiss in this movie. First there is the acting, where nearly ever character has at least one take (that made the final cut) where they have a noticeable pause because they either (A)forgot their line (B)got tongue tied on the dialogue Kevin Smith wrote up. The dialogue itself is the second major flaw in this movie. It's really hard to count this as a definite flaw when it does so much for the movie, but at the same time it is obvious that cons of the dialogue: (A)covering too much essential material too briefly (B)statements that are too long and elaborate for the given actors to do them justice (C)unrealistic detail and stream of conscious in the character's statements; out-weigh the positive aspects: (A)humorous anecdotes and tangents expressed through tirades (B)unique character interaction. This is not to say in any way that this movie is poor, but these attribute bring it considerably below the mark of 7.9 that IMDb voters have given it.

Clerks is Kevin Smith's first feature film and, in my opinion, his best so far. With this movie, he inaugurates the so-called View-Askew universe, whose places and characters will be present in many of his later movies. View Askew is the production house behind most of his following flicks, and it is formed by none other than Smith himself, and Scott Mosier, who we see in Clerks appearing as Snowball. At the time of shooting, Smith used to actually work at the convenience store in Leonardo, New Jersey depicted in the film. He worked at Quick Stop during the day, and filmed Clerks at night, so that, for the three weeks necessary to shoot, he was getting something like one hour sleep each night. The main characters impersonate that kind of comic-books and mainstream sci-fi movie fanatic, who will be present in many of his films, and is quite common in real life, as the nerd type. The roughness of the film, resulting from the low budget, which Smith managed somehow to put together himself, is definitely an attractive factor; in fact, stripped of all the pretence, and apparently nonplussed by the minimal scenery and (sometimes) heavily improvised props, the acting flows beautifully and the jokes acquire that much depth. We can appreciate more the directive skills of Kevin as a one-man filmmaker, and his ingeniousness, considering he also wrote the screenplay, and appeared in the movie as Silent Bob, the grumpy and taciturn partner of Jay, who dispenses gems of wisdom the few times he actually speaks. The black-and-white assigns lyricism to some of the scenes; for instance when Jay and Silent Bob dance at the sound of their ghetto-blaster, while Dante talks to Kaitlin inside the store. All in all, Clerks is a witty and ruthless comedy about anti-conformism, friendship and youth, where the diverseness of the characters helps us to grasp what actually are their common grounds, and appreciate the film that much more.

reviews.review_title: Why need enemies when you have a Randal
reviews.content: "Clerks" is a 1994 comedy written and directed by Kevin Smith starring Brian O'Hallorann and Jeff Anderson. I definitely know who Kevin Smith is and what major role he plays in the modern pop culture, but aside from his small role in "Die Hard 4.0" I've never actually come around watching his other films, especially his directorial works. After learning that this movie inspired Jason Reitman, who literally "grew up on the set of Ghostbusters" to become a director himself, I knew that this flick must be special in it's one way. I'm anything but disappointed with the outcome, because this film is the perfect example for cinematic minimalism. It can't be denied that it is a cheap production with an extremely low budget, but it's outstanding that it still manages to reach greatness. In this case it's the credit of Kevin Smith's excellently written screenplay that makes this flick what it is. Every single line of dialogue that's delivered in the course of the runtime has sheer and quick-witted brilliance in it. They are absolutely snappy and full of sarcasm and absurdity, but all the while never leave the extraordinarily high level of intelligence. Another achievement of the witty writing are the absolutely loveable and sympathetic main characters who definitely could exist like that in reality. Dante is totally relatable with his indecisiveness and carries the audience with his absentminded nature. Oh, and then there's Randal. With a friend like him you don't need enemies, no kidding. He appears to be an immeasurably incapable sociopath who still manages to live his life happily and hands down, at times says the absolute truth that's shaped by his own destructive world view and odd philosophy. But it's what makes it so enjoyably fascinating. The themes illuminated on this flick are mostly perverse and geeky, but conclusive and comprehensible at the same time without going into a too infantile direction. The plot is a loose adaptation of the Dante Alighieri story (no, seriously!) and is constructed episodically, into scenes that gave me the same feeling as classic sketches at time and honestly, gave me some of the most genuine laughs I've ever laughed in my entire life. It has running gags, one liners and hilarious situation comedy that totally match my sense of humour. It's also notable that it even features some more serious tone that gave the characters even more depth in the end. Smith knows how to create unique characters, without a doubt. I think this film had such an immense impact simply due to the fact that it examines so many important aspects of the lives of simple men, in this case hard working but underpaid desk clerks. It's a film from the simple people for the simple people. All in all, this minimalistic gem proves that a brilliant screenplay is all it might take to produce an iconic comedic gem. It's inspiring and relatable and matches my type of humour and is one of the most hilarious and original comedy flicks I've watched in the recent months. Absolutely funny experience I hoped will not be damaged by the sequel. Till then I enjoy it even more!

reviews.review_title: It has some good things about it but I don't find this particularly funny
reviews.content: A convenience shop worker agrees to go in to work on his day off. We follow him and his various encounters over the course of this day.This is the debut film of writer/director Kevin Smith. It's probably the best film of his that I've seen but in all honesty, I haven't liked any of them. This one is much like the others, yet has some charm and sense of place which I felt gave it some plus points. Shot on grainy black and for the tiny budget of $27,000, it truly is a small-scale affair that made an impact. As such it quickly developed a cult reputation with the slacker generation who empathised with its two central characters Dante and Randall. One of my main beefs with the film is that the latter character is played by Jeff Anderson who is truly one of the most horrible actors I have ever had the misfortune of witnessing. Every appallingly delivered line by him was like a low to medium strength punch to my face. And bad acting is something that I am generally ambivalent about, I mostly don't even notice it but Anderson really was so biscuit-takingly dreadful that it made me feel moderately unwell. The film's main strength is its script which does show some ambition on Smith's part but I felt it was mostly much less funny than it thought it was and some of the humour was downright rubbish. Overall though the production does have a certain ambiance and real-life feel which was its main positives I would say. It was followed up with other films which also featured the two, inexplicably popular characters Jay and Silent Bob, two examples being Mallrats (1995) and Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001), both of which I thought were banal and quite terrible. Clerks was better than those, which is faint praise but praise none-the-less.

reviews.review_title: It had it's moments, but this has to be one of the most over rated movies I have seen in a long time
reviews.content: I was so extremely excited to see Clerks, because I just saw recently on BRAVO the 100 funniest films of all time and Clerks was in the top 15, not to mention I have heard so much about this film from other viewers, they have said nothing but great things about Clerks. To them it was the funniest movie ever made, so I had to see this movie, I also remember finding out that this is how Jay and Silent Bob got their start, I loved their movie and appearances I've seen on TV.Donte is a clerk attendant who is in on his day off, he has found out some interesting "news" about his girlfriend, he is still in love with his high school sweetheart, Caitlin, and he has constant brainless customers who come up and pretty much scare him. He has a friend who works next door at the local video store who pretty much hates everyone except for Donte, but he constantly tells Donte what's wrong with his life and how to get everything straightened out.Clerks turned out to be annoying to me for the most part, I laughed a couple times, but I guess maybe I was expecting too much. It just didn't seem funny to me, more offensive if anything. I understand that there are some people who are into that, but this movie just seemed like an OK film to watch that I probably won't see again, sorry.6/10

reviews.review_title: A really good comedy that sometimes dangles on the edge of boredom
reviews.content: Kevin Smith is one of my favorite Directors, not only because he can direct, but he can create funny situations out of almost thin air. We see this in Mallrats, but this film...clerks, his first one is a bit out of the league.First of all the actors can't act, it's a fact. None of them really convinces me. And the script sometimes focuses to much on...nothing that it almost becomes intolerable to watch. Not even the directing is that good in this movie, but I think I speak for all Smith fans when I say that we are willing to forget and forgive most of this when it comes to clerks.Making a movie about two guys talking crap behind the counter of a quickstop is a very original and funny idea, but Smith does not pull this of all the way. He focuses to much on duologue, duologue that you know is very rehearsed, every line is presented with the utter most perfection which makes it less believable. But not all of it is bad, as I said before the idea is very original and some of the jokes really made me laugh.And let's not forget that this was his first real movie and that it took him from nothing to Hollywood in like a second, now thats impressive. It's also that fact that makes this movie so good, every aspiring director (including myself) sees this movie and if it weren't there before, now there is hope, hope that someday i will make it big time to. That is what makes this movie so great and thats what makes me love it.May the force be with you...always. Oh, and the Empire strikes back is way better than return of the Jedi.

reviews.review_title: the landmark beginning to a legendary saga
reviews.content: Kevin Smith's 'Clerks.' is one of the top comedies of all time, not only because it's got some of the most original, raunchiest, and hilarious jokes, but it can help a person whose life is not what it should be to re-examine their life. I did. It follows the founding fathers of Smith's saga, Dante and Randal, as they shove off boredom and laziness during one day on the job. Brian O'Halloran's Dante and Jeff Anderson's Randal are two of the most interesting characters you'll ever come by, especially Randal, who delivers a great and moving monologue at the end that is great for any actor to study. The way Smith blends the drama in with the dirty sex jokes, annoyance at customers, and Randal's constant wisecracks. Clerks became a Sundance hit and gained a massive following after its home release, including myself. If I could put one film that's not in the IMDb top 250 into it, Clerks would be it. It is just the film of its generation that defines most of America: lazy guys who don't really know what they want until that pivotal moment in their lives. Sorry USA, but it's true. Clerks is an absolute must see for any fan of comedy, and a necessity for movie fans. Kevin Smith, you have created a masterpiece that will never get old or die.10/10 --spy

This movie is not brilliant as people seem to think. I was hoping for more but was disappointed to find that this movied relied on the tried and true formula of white trash humor. For some reason people eat this stuff up. Admittedly there are a few well written parts but it is overshadowed by the crust.

reviews.review_title: Vulgar and yet very adept hilarity
reviews.content: This is a film in which the language and discussion are often crude, however the dialogue is crisp, authentic and not without philosophical wisdom. The film was made on a very low budget and so the cinematography is not terribly slick. It is a very funny film. Quirky, shocking and hilarious. I particularly like two scenes; the one with the eggs and one with the detective, but there are many many more that are excellent.

reviews.review_title: So, This Is Not a Documentary?
reviews.content: Clerks(1994) Review: Kevin Smith thinks of something original, A movie based on a single day on the job. being a clerk can definitely have it's moments that you can write a book about. Here's my review:Clerks is something else indeed. This movie is based on one long day and the events and things that happen around a small convenience and video store out in New Jersey. We have our two clerks, Dante and Randal. Dante is more reserved and will let out his frustrations behind the customers back and try to be professional. Randal is the up front balls-out clerk if annoyed, will let you know about it. These are the two types of clerks in the world.This movie is very raunchy and vulgar, but funny. The scary thing about this movie is that it is to real. Believe it or not, these type of things during the job can happen. I have seen my fare share and this movie can relate to ones who have or are doing customer service. Customers can be weird as hell or plain annoying.And don't think I forgot about Jay and Silent Bob. These two are a couple of unique characters.The Last Word: This movie seems too real. Also one of the best comedies of the year. This is not for everyone. This is rude, crude, vulgar, and raunchy as hell. If you have been a clerk, this movie will make total sense to you.

reviews.review_title: great script, torn apart by terrible cast
reviews.content: This movie had one of the smartest scripts in recent history, but it fell short of greatness, in my opinion, by its lack of any real acting skill the entire movie.  Brian O'Halloran did a despicable job as Dante, and succeeded only in getting on my nerves.  The supporting cast also lacked any real substance.  I don't know why Kevin Smith allowed Mr. O'Halloran in the rest of his movies, unless it was to make fun of him in both Mallrats and Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back.  Jason Mewes and Mr. Smith were wonderful as usual, but if you only want to see them you would do better to rent one of the others in the series.  It was an okay start to a wonderful series of movies, I only wish the acting was a little better.

This really basic (arguably boring), really cheap ($25-50,000), very poorly acted film with zero plot has a 7.7 rating? How does that make any sense? I give it full credit for being a totally cheap independent film, basically a demo, and grossing millions. But, man, the acting and execution is terrible. Dazed and Confused should be a 9.5 if this is a 7.7...

Well, one thing I have seen people complain about in the past is the fact that this movie is not in color although it is a rather modern movie - at least compared to /actual/ black and white movies. My girlfriend said she liked the second part, but she cannot watch modern black and white movies, which is why she avoided this one. That part, though, does not bother me.About its humor, I cannot complain either. This movie made me laugh a lot and I do not regret watching it at all.The only thing that bothers me a little, which is why I 'only' rated it 8/10 stars is the fact that it a)does not have a solid story, and b)barely shows any places other than the Quick Stop Market (I hope I got the name correct). All in all, though, 'Clerks' is a very good comedy movie!

After all these years, I still don't see why people love this film so much. Sure it's funny in places, but so was "Mallrats".This low budget film chronicles a day in the life of two miserable, unhappy convenience store workers, the indecisive Dante and the obnoxious Randall. Dante's inability to deal with the punches life throws his way and his inability to do anything to elevate himself above his status in life, along with his obsession with an ex-girlfriend and lack of appreciation for his current girlfriend, has made him a whiny, weak willed and some what feminine man. Randall deals with life by being a jerk who treats everybody like crap and exploits his "friend" Dante for all he's worth.It may have more off beat philosophy about life in it than "Mallrats", but at least the characters in "Mallrats" were sympathetic in a crude, slacker kind of way. These guys just get on your nerves.Ultimately, the film is more memorable for introducing Jay (Jason Mewes) and Silent Bob (writer director Kevin Smith), who later became staples of Smith's films than anything else.

Clerks. (1994) C-92 min. D: Kevin Smith. Brian O'Halloran, Jeff Anderson, Marilyn Ghigliotti, Lisa Spoonhauer, Jason Mewes, Kevin Smith, Scott Mosier, Walter Flanagan, Al Berkowitz. $27,000 B/W film about a day in the lives of two unhappy clerks, one who works at a convenience store and the other who works at a video store. Smith's first film, often times very funny, but tends to drag on a bit and some of the acting is slightly bland. Some laugh out loud moments, such as the offscreen sexual encounter between the main character's ex-girlfriend and...well, I won't spoil it for you. But offscreen is indeed where it belongs once we find out the messy details. The big-screen debut of Jay and Silent Bob, who play drug dealers who spend their days outside the stores (but business seems to be very bad). Originally rated NC-17 for sexually explicit dialogue. RATING: 6 out of 10. Rated R for graphic sexual dialogue.

Did I say underrated? Sorry, I meant overrated. Well, a friend of mine recommended this movie, notably after I asked him 'if he could recommend me a few good movies'. Needless to say, this so-called friend is in the defriendzone now. No, seriously, this movie has to be viewed as a 'cult-movie', shot with minimal budget, in black-and-white, by a young director and with amateur actors. So you have to give the director credit for that. Taken that all in account, this still makes the movie overrated. See above and below for reasons and proof. I would rate it 5, but I rated it 0, to have it removed from the IMDb top- 250.If you want to compare this movie with another movie, check out 'Man bites dog', a Belgian movie, made with less budget (<50.000$), shot in the same year, also in black-and- white, using young and unprofessional actors. What a difference in quality!Amazing dialogue, inventive script, convincing acting, unique characters, humour,... Man bites dog has it all.People in Belgium and France (and French Canada I suppose) can recite whole dialogues by heart. Just like Americans can with Pulp Fiction.Benoit Poelvoorde, the main actor, is really talented and this movie was the start of his career. A career that comprises leading roles in some of the biggest movies.Just saying... If you want to compare. Enjoy

reviews.review_title: Great Start for one of the world's best directors
reviews.content: Clerks was Kevin Smith's first film it is one of my favorite movies it introduced two of the world's most recognizable characters (Jay and Silent Bob) with their first film debut as the dope dealers they are today. With Dante who's not even supposed to be there today and Randal who enjoys nothing more than torturing Dante. Jay (Jason Mewes)and Silent Bob (Kevin Smith) are recurring characters in Smith's View Askewniverse they also appear in Mallrats,Chasing Amy (for one scene)Dogma, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back, and the soon to be released Clerks 2 this movie is a movie only meant probably for the age range of 15-22 because it says the F*** word over one hundred times if you have little kids DO NOT LET THEM WATCH THIS it might put ideas in their head that you don't want there.

reviews.review_title: Kevin Smith's only good film so far
reviews.content: Having recently been in film school, `Clerks' quickly became an awe-inspiring film among the film geeks that I knew.  This guy Kevin Smith comes out of nowhere with this cheaply made film that he financed himself and knocks the socks off the indie world, while taking some prizes at Cannes  it was everything that any of us had (and still in some ways do) dreamed of.  Remarkably, until now, 10 years later, I had only seen bits and pieces of it, though I had (unfortunately) sat through his next three films.Watching Clerks was like being in film school again.  The grainy black and white cinematography, the horrible acting (by actors who, for the most part, had no prior film experience) and the general feeling of near chaos that accompany a student film.  What sets the film apart however, is the incredible script.  Even when dished out by less than great actors, this script is a punchy plethora of pop culture delivered with rapid-fire pacing. I am a huge fan of Kevin Smith because in my opinion, he is a Gen X version of Martin Scorsese in that he doesn't just make films, he lives and breathes them, and seems to enjoy furthering film education.  Unfortunately, while I respect Kevin Smith the man, I'm not a fan of his films post-Clerks. (Although I did really enjoy the short-lived Clerks animated series.) Clerks, however, shows raw talent and is definitely a ground breaking piece of work that was and probably continues to serve as inspiration to fledgling filmmakers and film geeks alike.  --Shelly

The characters are consistent and well-drawn, and the dialogue strikes the perfect balance between clever and relatable. Maybe the greatest argument for artistic intuition and commitment being more vital than any amount of money or experience.

reviews.review_title: Things are not going to change unless you change them
reviews.content: Annoyed by odd customers, confused by a brash girlfriend and perplexed by the inability to change circumstances for the better; it is one bad development after another for Quick Stop clerk Dante. A friend next door tries to loosen Dante up, but this just seems to rile him more. Dante doesn't know what he wants from life.Filmed in black and white and for a meager budget, Clerks delighted me with its rawness, youthful spirit and humor despite its imperfections. It is far from a typical Hollywood film. The straightforward, jarring and hilarious conversations between characters are the crux of the film. I first saw Clerks in 1994 with my girlfriend Carolyn at the uptown theater in Minneapolis. Clerks made a big impression on us and we kept coming back for similar independent films.

reviews.review_title: The Kevin Smith Movie that Really Holds up!
reviews.content: This movie did a lot with what it had and it is a great movie. I think I like it better than when it was released. It has smart writing, relatable topics, and it is above all else, sincere! If you can handle a bit of unneeded crass humor, I think you'll get a lot from this movie that made a lot of out of a little. Maybe the restraints of a small budget and few resources helped Smith and his associates focus on what really matters in a movie and that is having something to say and making something entertaining. It is a bare bones black and white indie film with great writing and simple scenes that speaks to the messy process of trying to make something out of your life... and it is a terrific movie.

reviews.review_title: Self-indulgence to the max, too average humor
reviews.content: I would say "love it or hate it", but really it's not about that. I don't "hate" this. I'm biased that 90's movies are the best, so if anything I tried harder than necessary to get into it. The random conversations, the intentionally stupid-witty dialog, the black n white angle, 90's youth culture with crossover alt metal in the background with the VHS rental and everything...But if this is basically a collection of short comedy sketches sown together to make something of a movie, and it can be mostly judged for its smaller parts, then it really isn't top notch stuff, and overall isn't anything more than a self-indulgent ultra-subjective account of impressions. It's fine that a film can be super subjective, but it does need to deliver in the quality of whatever craft it handles. Here, the humor is clear. It's obvious the edge the film is operating to reach.I'm not now deciding for everyone and saying it's horrible and no one should watch, but yes indeed I am. Just kidding. But it's pretty ordinary stuff. If it's your thing, you dig it, it means something in your personal life's development, it's nostalgic...perfect. But if you're an eager comedy fan and don't necessarily want to hear about hockey and edgy Star Wars opinions with 'cocks and dicks' every five minutes, and are looking for top notch, well constructed 90's "standup" more universal material, go straight for Seinfeld, it's outright superior stuff, or in a similar standup-style flick from 3 years earlier, check out Steve Oedekerk's "High Strung", absolutely hilarious.4/10.

"Clerks" is the first in Kevin Smith's saga about a bunch of people who live in Jersey, or the View Askewniverse, as many hardcore Smith fans like me have come to call it. This one focuses on Dante, who works in Quick Stop, and Randal, who works at RST Video next door. I thought Brian O'Halloran did a good job as Dante, but I thought that Jeff Anderson out acted him. But I think the thing that stands out to most people is that this was the first appearance of Jay & Silent Bob. I love these characters, even though this was by far the least important role they've had in his movies. All in all, you can tell it was an amateur film, notice how the camera never really moves. But it's a good amateur film, and it's one that I watch all the time. It's my favorite from Kevin Smith by far due mainly to the dialog. I can't wait for "Clerks 2" in 06.

Now don't get me wrong, I thought this was a good movie with a number of fantastic scenes that really got me laughing, but I wouldn't say this was a great movie.  Some of the humor in this film is genuinely funny and actually quite hilarious, but some of it is just the same gross-out jokes that you've seen in numerous other films these days.  I'm not sure why the film was made in black and white, but I guess the director has his reasons. (Cheaper maybe?)The story (or lack thereof) is pretty interesting, and as far as I can tell, pretty original.  As I mentioned above, there are some great scenes in the film, for instance; I love the conversation between Dante and Randal about the Star Wars Death Star and which film is better, "Empire" or "Jedi". Great stuff!Some of the acting is sub-par and obviously scripted, but at other times, the acting is quite good.  For the most part, the actors all did a fine job.The characters in the film are mostly pretty interesting, and well done.  I really liked the characters of Dante Hicks, Randal Graves and Silent Bob. Veronica and Caitlin were ok too, but nothing special there.  Personally, I can't stand Jay, or maybe it's the actor Jason Mewes, I'm not sure.  I know he's supposed to be annoying, but he's just too annoying for me.  He can't keep from swearing an absurd amount of times, has no respect for anyone and is incapable of making a funny joke.  Silent Bob is great, only Kevin should find a new side-kick for him.  Some of the other (insignificant) characters were just plain stupid in my opinion.  The one I have in mind is the "Perfect Dozen of Eggs" guy.  What the heck was with that?  DUMB!  Not only was the idea for the character dumb, but the character looked stupid as well.All in all, I wouldn't recommend this film to just anyone.  I'd probably first recommend watching some of Kevin Smith's later films ("Mallrats", "Chasing Amy", and "Dogma") and if you like any of those films, then give this one a shot.  If you don't like any of those I seriously doubt you are going to like "Clerks".  Well, in any case, thanks for reading.  I hope you enjoy the film should you see it.-Chris

reviews.review_title: An absolute classic and inspiring piece of indie cinema
reviews.content: Timely and clever- Clerks is pure proof you don't need a huge Hollywood budget to make a great movie. Needless to say, Clerks is legendary for starting both Kevin Smith's film career and its comically low budget which amounts to less than 30k. Thankfully though, Smith is able to achieve exactly what he needs to throughout the film to make it work, making for an oddly entertaining and subtle little comedy masterpiece. It has its flaws from time to time, it may talk a little too much about sex at times, and it can be a bit heavy handed- but it also proves to be quite a brilliant satire on the mundane and average working class of the world- and somehow manages to make it fun and interesting as well. The actors throughout are pretty good, my favorite of the bunch being Jeff Anderson as Randal- who can seem a bit one note at times- but has enough charm to spare. Brian O'Halloran also provides a good performance, and the two have a great chemistry throughout the flick. In the end, Clerks is a rather brilliant comedy that shows that not only anyone can make a movie, but with enough dedication, anyone can make a good movie too.My Rating: 9.5/10.
