reviews.review_title: How was this rated so high?
reviews.content: I went into this movie expecting laughs galore. To be fair, i watched half of the movie before turning it off, so I'm only commenting on the first half. I love all types of comedy, but this movie was abysmal. The acting was HORRENDOUS, with the exception of Jay (and I guess Silent Bob). The other actors sucked the big one. They sounded like they were reading off of cue cards, with no timing in between lines of different characters. I admit that the movie's story had some type of depth, but it was lost to me due to the horrible acting and total lack of funny scenes. As I said, I didn't laugh one time. Very highly rated by other users, so maybe it was just me, but this is quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen (I've walked out on 1 other movie in my 30+ years of life).

Clerks is a rather uneven comedy: some dialogues are funny and well written, some quite not. Some scenes are interesting and well thought-out, some are just boring. The one thing you have to acknowledge though is the movie being innovative, you don't often see a comedy behind closed doors (a bit edulcorated here but still), in black and white.The two main characters are good and them being opposites established a good chemistry.The direction is rather good even if the black and white is a bit off, but considering the low budget, Kevin Smith did a great job.

just cant watch until the end of this film. it feels like a microcosm of a 90s teenage life with so many flaws. The main one being that it just tries so hard. The dialogue is almost attempting to be Shakespearean at times- with so many words fit into a tightly-packed scene that there is no room for comprehension and analysis. Dogma was clever, but this is pure tripe. To make a cult film about adolescence you don't need to be so desperate to prove your directing chops, as Kevin Smith was. Almost famous did a much better job of encapsulating teenage angst and subcultures, whilst maintaining an air of 'cool'.While the visuals are all there for a 90s movie, with a b&w lens, the dialogue is just so unnatural and forced from sub-par actors that it become unwatchable. Anyone who claims that this is a gem and underrated work of genius needs a massive reality check and should stop reading media studies. I've no doubt Kevin Smith can write a good script,but this is not one of them!

The beauty of Clerks is that it realizes that its main characters are losers and thus doesn't even screw with a plot because quite frankly, when's the last time a Store Clerk shared an entertaining story that encompassed more than, `A real freak came into the store today, and . . .'  These guys have no lives.  We don't care about their lives.  So Clerks shows off anecdotal moments from a day--strange customers, weird moments, conversations with no point that lead nowhere . . . and that's the film.  And you know what?  I like it more than most comedies out there.What I find frightening is that the Clerks cast has more development than most epics, tragedies, dramas.  The characters don't have the plot to trip over, so everything in the film builds towards the characters; what's even sadder is the fact you wouldn't want these- two losers to be some of the more developed characters you'll find on the rental shelf, but they are. 
Everyone wants to rave about plot and how important it is and put all your focus into just the plot, so it's kinda queer that we don't have more good plot driven films.  Then when the plot is actually good, the characters are mediocre because everything was put into the plot . . . so we have a plot we don't care about because we hate the characters.  When is the industry going to wake up and realize that storytelling is more than just one or two elements?  That you have to combine everything together roughly equally?With that said, why do I still like Clerks since it has no plot to speak of? If it had a plot, would I have cared about it with these two losers at the helm?  Kevin Smith knew better, and set out with a different agenda . . . plot wasn't the point of Clerks.  This is one of the rare times when someone goes to the other end of the spectrum without being offensive, but just goes to show how overrated the `plot' can be.  As idiotic and worthless as the Dante and Randal and the people in the Clerks environment are . . . it's still entertaining without a plot.  I wouldn't want my collection of DVDs to all be like Clerks, but the film is a nice film to pop in and ask, `How important is the plot when everything is said and done?'

reviews.review_title: Clerks — Low budget debut movie of a cerebral director
reviews.content: Clerks is a difficult movie to rate, because it's an acquired taste. Once you understand's Kevin Smith's sense of story telling and style of humor, then you'll appreciate his debut flick.This piece presents to us seemingly unrelated life events in a day of two clerks. Their dialogs present facts of life in a basic yet articulate way with a slight ring of nerdy pot smokers.It's black and white, with shaky camera shots, awkward angles, amateur acting, and seedy sets that scream low budget. Yet, the ideas and philosophy on display will make you think.Overall, it entertaining, but to fully appreciate it, you better have a good Smith education, so start by watching Dogma, or Chasing Amy, or even Mallrats. If you like them, then you're ready for this film, and you will most likely enjoy it.

Doesn't have a strong plot, did not laugh and was a little complex so it's budget. But, I am impressed with Kevin Smiths 27,000 budget and how you can make a movie with that money. So the movie itself is not interesting, but I respect the film on its budget

I was 20 when this movie came out and thought it an absolute masterpiece. Yes we always knew the acting was bad but the originality and the writing more than made up for it. On top of that I was doing a lot of NJ community theater at the time and there were three people in the movie with small parts that I had worked with which added to my enjoyment of the film. After watching the movie numerous times in my early 20s I did not watch it again untill I was about 38. Or tried to watch it I should say. Wow what a difference that time made. The acting was even worse than I remembered but everything I found brilliant the first time around was missing. The writing was childish and at points gross. It was literally like I was watching something written by a 14 year old. No amount of originality could make up for these unlikable characters in unbelievable situations. In the end I couldn't finish it. I gave up 30-45 minutes in. It left me questioning my younger self just how stupid was I at 20? If you have fond memories from your youth of this movie keep the memories and save yourself the uncomfortable experience of trying to enjoy this one as an adult. To say it hasn't aged well is an understatement.

I watched this for the first time the other day, expecting - after noting all the plaudits - it to be something special. I came away thinking it had its moments and felt unusual, but overall, the whole thing didn't impress me for various reasons: 1. The lines often sounded unnatural and not as you'd expect the characters to speak( maybe that's an intentional part of the comedy? ) 2. The acting was a very mixed bag; 3. There were few funny moments; 4. The story was far too limited - with a severe lack of really fun, memorable moments.I can sort of appreciate why lots of people really like this film, but I think it's over-hyped. I can't understand why anyone would give it more than 7/10. I think Kevin Smith and his crew did a good job, but it's not anything sensational imo. It's a reasonable bit of down to earth, amateurish entertainment - nothing more.

reviews.review_title: Dialouge So Sharp & Cutting,You Can Get A Close,Clean Shave From It
reviews.content: If you're a fan of low budget,independently produced cinema with a subversive edge,then Clerks is for you. Kevin Smith made his feature film debut with this kitchen sink,black & white film,that may remind some viewers of some of the early Jim Jarmusch,or Hal Hartley films (who both get an acknowledgment in the closing credits), with a (then)no name cast,shot mostly in a convenient store (with some extra footage shot in a video shop next door). The plot has Dante Hicks (played to the hilt,by a damaged looking Brian O'Hallorin),who is experiencing what has to be the absolute worst day ever in his life. He is called into work on his day off,when he is supposed to hook up with his pals to play some hockey. His lazy,good for nothing slacker of a friend,Randal,who works next door in the video mart (yeah...right!), manages to be nothing short of a major thorn in Dante's side by being obnoxious to customers. The various weird customers that Dante hates dealing with. Among others,Dante finds out his ex girlfriend is getting married,which launches Dante into a downward spiral of depression. Toss in a couple of equally obnoxious pot dealers (Jason Mewes,as Jay & Kevin Smith,himself as Silent Bob,who lives up to his namesake)to up the ante,and you have yourself the makings for a caustic comedy that will turn some off & attract a cadre of followers. This film had a bit of controversy,due to the fact that the goons at the MPAA wanted to slap this film with an NC-17 for the nearly non stop barrage of vulgar language & crude sex jokes. In the end,though, Smith appealed & got the 'R' rating he wanted. This is the film that would spawn a sequel, an short lived animated series (only six episodes,although only two were ever aired on ABC),not to mention turning Jay & Silent Bob into an icon of pop culture. Not a film for every one's tastes,but those who endure,will be pleased. Rated 'R' for wall to wall profanity & sex related jokes (although nobody in this film removes so much as a shoe).

reviews.review_title: The only film Kevin Smith ever made that can be considered a classic
reviews.content: Along with this masterpiece, Kevin Smith put out a few other decent comedies in his early career. It's unfortunate that the only thing Kevin Smith does now that's funny is post teary eyed selfies on twitter.Clerks was his absolute best and you can see he tried to squeeze everything he could out of the success of his first film. Even to go on and create 2 awful sequels and an animated series; none of which capture the spirit of the first film. This movie is truly a lightning in a bottle scenario, they didn't know what they had and were just making a simple movie about a group of characters...

Here we have an adorable little movie, seemingly shot on security cameras, with maybe five speaking roles, and where all the action takes place within, I'd say, about a five mile radius in Middle-Of-Nowhere New Jersey.  And it is legendary for having been paid for mostly by credit cards."Clerks" is better than all of the monster-budget Simpson/Bruckheimer "Stuff Blowing Up" movies combined.I think that's all that need be said.  I will say that, while the movie is rated R for sex, it's all just talk.And another thing.  You will appreciate this movie twice as much if you ever worked in a lousy video store, and had to face the Moral Dilemma of whether you should go to the nearby larger competing store that happens to have the movie you want.

I am a huge fan off Kevin Smith, I like every film he has made, he has well written and quirky dialogue in his scripts which make all his characters come to life and become people we can relate with extremely well.What I love about this film is the fact its such a basic plot, like in most movie (and I don't have anything against this) the characters embark on some huge quest, mission or revenge plan and thats all great but with Clerks. thats what 90% of the worlds population are like, they go to work and hate every single last minute off it and the world constantly kicks them when their down.This is a landmark in independent film making and should be released on DVD soon in the U.K. God dammit'.10 out of 10

reviews.review_title: One Of The Funniest Movies Of All-Time. An Excellent And Hilarious Comedy/Cult Classic Debut From Kevin Smith.
reviews.content: Clerks is one of the funniest and most memorable Comedies of all-time and an excellent and hilarious Comedy Cult Classic that combines fine direction,a good cast,a terrific script and a wonderful soundtrack. With those elements Clerks is a great Comedy,a classic of Independent cinema and Kevin Smith at his best.Set in Leonardo,New Jersey,Clerks tells the day in the life story of Dante Hicks(Brian O'Halloran) and Randal Graves(Jeff Anderson),two twenty somethings and best friends who work at a Quick Stop convenience store and video store next door to each other. While at work,Dante and Randal have to deal with hilarious situations involving offbeat and annoying customers as well as dealing with themselves. There is also a Marijuana dealing duo named Jay(Jason Mewes) and Silent Bob(Kevin Smith)who hang outside the stores and add to the insanity.Released in 1994,Clerks is a brilliant and hilarious low budget Comedy that marked the directorial debut of writer-director Kevin Smith who sold his Comic Book collection and maxed out credit cards to make the film on a 27,000 dollar budget and in Black and White. Clerks not only was a critical and commercial success but also a Cult Classic that was the first in Kevin Smith's View Askewniverse Comedies which also included Mallrats(1995),Chasing Amy(1997),Dogma(1999),Jay And Silent Bob Strike Back(2001)and Clerks II(2006)and also introduced the famous stoner duo Jay and Silent Bob. Clerks is one of those films that is a Comedy classic from the moment you first watch,a funny and offbeat film that gives viewers a outrageous tale of what it's like to work at a convenience store showing how dull and boring the job is with moments of bizarre and weird things. The Comedy and laughs in Clerks are hilarious and will make your stomach hurt and cry your eyes out because the humor in Clerks has a great balance between going over the top and being realistic with the over the top nature being with the characters and dialog that gives the Comedy a stylish feel that is in a world of it's own and the Comedy is at times cynical and in your face but not mean spirited. The Comedy is realistic(and demented)in showing how the characters Dante and Randal deal with customers and their work place how the two really don't want to be there at all. The Comedy in Clerks would also be the beginning of Smith's signature style that would be in Smith's other View Askew movies:pop culture references to the Star Wars films and other movies,Comic Books,Superheros and sexual related jokes and all of started here in Clerks and would continue in his later films. Clerks is a movie that is not only funny but also at times(due to it's low budget and Black and White photography)has a gritty fly one the wall style that isn't pretty or beautiful but real and accurate showing viewers a world that exists in our everyday life even if the world of Clerks is silly. I also love the fact the movie takes place over the course of one day because when a film is set on one day anything can happen. The main characters Dante and Randal are classic characters from Kevin Smith's mind the classic example of the straight man and funny guy. Like I said before,Dante and Randal don't want to work at their corner stores but feel like they have to be there because they have nothing else to do with their life and have no ambitions. With Dante we see that the character is miserable and in a funk he's a College dropout,he has to deal with the relationships in his life whether it's Randal,his present girlfriend or ex-girlfriend and the way the relationships are handled is funny. Randal is different person from Dante because where Dante is miserable and upset about his life,Randal loves the way things are for himself and doesn't have any high ambitions for his life and does things his way not giving a crap about the customers or about what anyone else thinks. The friendship between Dante and Randal while hectic and crazy feels genuine and real and you will feel that despite their differences the two care for one another. The relationship and banter between Dante and Randal is one of the things that make the movie a classic and a great film. The screenplay by Kevin Smith is terrific and funny,with Smith giving the movie and it's characters dialog and scenes that are raunchy and offbeat and done in a way that is profane and ironic only way Kevin Smith knows how(so profane that the Clerks originally received an NC-17 from the MPAA). The ending of Clerks is amazing because while it's funny it also makes you think with a hint of truth and depth. A great ending.The cast is good. Brian O'Holloran is wonderful and funny as Dante,with O'Holloran playing the laughs in a straight manner. Jeff Anderson is terrific and hilarious as Randal,with Anderson stealing every scene he's in. Marylin Ghigliotti does a good job as Veronica,Dante's girlfriend. Lisa Spoonauer does a fine job as Caitlin Bree,Dante's ex-girlfriend. Jason Mewes and Kevin Smith are fantastic and laugh out loud funny as Jay And Silent Bob,Mariuana dealers that hangout in front of the store.The direction by Kevin Smith is simple but great,with Smith pointing the camera and shooting and at times using handled camera movements to a nice effect. Fine direction,Smith.The soundtrack for Clerks(which was more expensive than the entire film)has great songs by Soul Asylum(Can't Even Tell),Alice In Chains(Got Me Wrong),Bad Religion(Leaders And Followers),Corrision Of Conformity(Big Problems),Love Among Freaks(Clerks,Berserker)Girls Against Boys(Kill The Sax Player),Stabbing Westward(Violent Mood Swings),Bash & Pop(Making Me Sick),Seaweed(Go Your Own Way),Supernova(Chewbacca),The Jesus Lizard(Panic In Cicero)and Golden Smog(Shooting Star). Amazing soundtrack.In final word,if you love Kevin Smith,Comedies,Independent Films or films in general,I highly suggest you see Clerks,an excellent,hilarious and unforgettable Comedy/Cult Classic that you can watch again and again. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

"Clerks", was a film I liked even more watching the second time around. If there's anything to say about Kevin Smith's filmography, is that a majority of it will eventually grow on you. Brought to Sundance 1994, and made on a shoe string budget of 27.5 grand (All shot at the convenient store where Smith worked, filming only at night during closed hours). "Clerks" remains a tour-de-force of Independent Cinema.Kevin Smith has become an entertainment giant over the last couple of years. I am an avid listener to his pod-casts, comic books, approach on writing and overall court jester dissection on pop culture. "Clerks" represents a fantastic debut for a man not so perfected from a directing standpoint, but for a writer anyone who has read his scripts can clearly see a passion.The story follows a day in the life of Dante (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal (Jeff Anderson), two slackers who work in rundown convenient stores next to each other. Throughout their work day they deal with random customers, proceed with recreational activities and put up with obnoxious yet lovable pot dealing duo Jay (Jason Mewes) and Silent Bob (Kevin Smith). As well as just trying to get through the day, they also discuss very important issues, such as whether or not the contractors deserved to die while rebuilding the second Death Star in "Star Wars Episode 6: Return of the Jedi" (1983).Wonderful 20's angst dialogue, mixed with acting that is very good considering the movie is made up of local friends and family. It put them all on the map, and paved Kevin Smith's name in the concrete of todays very popular Independent genre.Final Verdict: Ultimately it's the movie for the MTV generation, and a wonderful film made by a man in his early 20's. A very earnest and ambitious beginning from a guy who clearly chose the right profession. 8/10. Props to the soundtrack too (That cost more than the film to produce).

Clerks Starring Brian O' Halloran And Jeff Anderson As The Two Employee Clerks Also Starring is Marilyn Ghigliotti, Lisa Spoonauer And But Not Lease Kevin Smith Who Wrote And Directed This Film Clerks Also Too Plays Silent Bob And Jason Mewes As Jay The Two Icon Famous Characters Kevin Smith's Clerks is Again Funny And Entertaining Movie Of The Mid-90s.

Watching this movie, and most every other movie that takes place on the East Coast, it makes me realize how lucky I am to a) not live on the East Coast, b) not talk with a New Yawk/New Joisey accent (pathetic) and c) not live like these bums in the movie.

A low budget film that delivers. Like El Mariachi, this is not only a watchable movie, it is REWATCHABLE. It is funny, interesting and it makes you think afterwards.One of the more notable effects of this film is that the viewer goes from feeling sympathy for the main character to realizing that the main character is his own worst enemy. In fact, he is not a very nice guy at all. No one in this movie is particularly nice. Everyone has the feel of a group of rats in a cage in a laboratory growing more and more irritable as time passes.I don't think any description of the various situations in the movie are necessary here, due to the movie's gushing reviews. I'll simply recommend it as a great comedy and a fine movie and leave it at that...

Vast sums were spent on movies such as Titanic, Waterworld, Cutthroat Island, Phantom Menace, and all we were left with was vapid, plotless crap, aimed at a 13-year-old with an IQ of about 6 and just enough social graces to get the popcorn to his mouth without drooling too much.Then Kevin Smith gets together a bunch of his pals and about 43 cents and makes one of the funniest, truest movies of the 90s.Might this bizarre paradox indicate that Hollywood is run by a bunch of retards?Discuss.

reviews.review_title: Cigarettes and slurpees- life behind the counter.
reviews.content: My son told me to see this- Despite the language- my husband considered foul- I found some real humor in this.  Dante and Randall are unforgettable in their portrayal of the day to day inanity of suburban life for today's youth.  The gray tones add to the story.  Most of all Veronica was a stand-up woman- who didn't accept Dante's guff.

reviews.review_title: Just because they serve you, doesn't mean they like you.
reviews.content: After seeing 'Dogma', and having found out about the four other Kevin Smith-produced View Askew films, I rushed down to the video store to rent 'Clerks.', 'Mallrats' and 'Chasing Amy'. Unfortunately, 'Clerks.' was the only one of the aforementioned three that they had - but no matter - after all the hype surely even just one of the films would be enough. Right?Well, to start off with, I didn't know that 'Clerks.' was an independent film made entirely in black and white (more fool me). After my initial dismay, I continued watching... niggling doubts aside I actually enjoyed myself. It's a charming, witty story about two clerks who are completely bored with their jobs. But before the day is out, a customer will die, a girlfriend will confess to giving 27 guys blowjobs, someone will get a bill for selling cigarettes to a 4-year old and someone will have sex with a dead guy! It's about as farfetched as it isn't farfetched, but no matter how you see it - it's a very funny movie worthy of all the Sundance accolation it got.

The hilarious first entry into Kevin Smith's Jersey trilogy and is by far the best. This movie prooves that a lot can come from very little. This low budget black and white comedy is really no plot at all, it is the day in the life of a convieniance strore clerk Dante Hicks (Brian O'Halloran) who gets called in to work on his day off. He has several encounters with his girlfriend, his best friend who runs the video store next to his, a past lover, a bunch of unconventionaly hilarious  customers and the ever so popular Jay and Silent Bob who have appeared in all of Smith's movies to date. The script is very harsh and sexual graphic and although this may tunr off some more closed minded viewers it makes the movie much more effective. The movie also touches on serious issues as marraige, cheating and death but never taking itself to seriously as to become boring. So if you are a fan of Smiths controversial style or you just watch this to see Jay and Silent Bob it is a pleasing bit of social comentary that is sure to entertain.

Clerks has, in my opinion, been ridiculously overrated by critics and moviegoers alike. It's uneven and much of the humor is sophomoric.
Still, I like it and purchased the DVD. There are moments that are laugh out loud funny. If you're looking for a few good laughs on a Saturday night you should definitely rent it.

reviews.review_title: A great debut--but I think he's capable of even better work!
reviews.content: Over the years, I have really enjoyed Smith's comic book writing, but this is the only film so far I have seen him direct. My cinephilic friends tend to dismiss his recent works, but this was very enjoyable. I like the influence he has had on independent cinema. 1994 certainly proved to be an important year for it, with the smash successes that independent studios had with 'Clerks' and 'Pulp Fiction'. I hope he sticks to directing films that he himself writes. I have the feeling he wants to expand his horizons but isn't quite sure how to go about it without alienating his huge fan base. I have great confidence in him, and feel that if he puts his heart into it, he can be a great filmmaker, instead of a good one. I think for him to do so, he could do himself a great service and read a few less comic books and watch a lot more movies, particularly by the Hollywood greats from the Golden Age, such as Sir Alfred Hitchcock, Howard Hawks, Raoul Walsh and John Ford. It would be quite exciting to see what he comes up with, once his creative juices are recharged.

Sometimes a movie comes around that has no real social significance, one that isn't looking to change how you see the world, doesn't challenge us to look at ourselves and yet manages to do all three.Oh, and it makes you laugh so hard that you cry! The story follows Dante and Randall during a typical day for them. Along the way, we see all sorts of stereotypes coming and going during the movie and we see how these people relate to one another. Each person who comes in to the store is a caricature of someone we all know. I think that's why this movie is so good.There is nothing really outrageous about the plot, there is nothing that you say "Hey...that could never happen!" In fact, you get the feeling that these things happen far too often! This movie was brilliantly written and directed. It is subdued and low key.Oh yeah! It also has Jay and Silent Bob! How can you resist a movie like this!

This movie is obviously made on a low budget, but that doesn't mean that it's bad. Actually it's pretty original comedy, though I've seen some similar movies, but this one is the best one. It's similar with movie Coffee and Cigarettes (which is made almost 10 years later, but it's also a better known film) only it's better. The bigger part of the movie takes dialogs (mostly about sex, sometimes about drugs and movies). There are some funny moments, but I wouldn't call it a very funny comedy, but it's always interesting and that's what's good about it. I think this movie will be interesting for different sorts of people, because it's pretty colorful for a black and white movie.

reviews.review_title: "I'm not even supposed to be here today!!!!"
reviews.content: This was Kevin Smith's directorial debut.  This tells the impeccable story about two clerks: Dante, a convenience store clerk.  And Randall, a video store clerk who's really no help to his friend Dante.  Together they encounter annoying customers, their girlfriends, a funeral, and get a little help from their friends, Jay and Silent Bob.     I thought it was rather intriguing that this movie was in black and white, though it was never really specified why Kevin Smith filmed it in black and white.    And to top it all off Dante and Randall still had to show up for work on what was supposed to be their day off!  This flick had a lot of funny moments from beginning to end!     If you're a fan of Kevin Smith's work, check out his first movie, Clerks! And please if you want to, skip the ridiculous animated series that was shown on ABC.  See the movie instead!  At least they are real people!  My hat also goes off to Jason Mewes!  May the talented young actor be in more comedies and Kevin Smith movies to come in the future!

reviews.review_title: Lewd, crude, and amateurish. Also perfect.
reviews.content: Kevin Smith's slice-of-life comedy about two Jersey-area clerks is crude, amateurish, and unapologetically vulgar. But it's also perfect.True, the movie clearly has "microbudget" written all over it, but the minimal production values actually work in favor of the movie, effectively underscoring Dante's and Randal's utter laziness. And despite their complete resignation to a meaningless existence and an unfulfilling job, the two main characters are more thrilling and likable than most comic book action heroes. Most people can identify with Dante's fear of advancement and Randal's anti-authoritarian creed.There are numerous technical flaws and some unexplained gaps in the plot, but all limitations aside, Smith and his crew did an amazing job at telling a very funny and relatable story with very little resources. The performances are impressive and surprisingly nuanced given the actors inexperience, and the writing is nothing short of brilliant.Kevin Smith has gone on to make some truly excellent work ("Chasing Amy" immediately comes to mind) but Clerks will probably forever remain his most unique and compulsively watchable film.

A low budget film that ranks as one of the best films of the year, Clerks is a brilliant, hilarious, lively comedy following the lives of a store clerk and of a video clerk and their 'friends'.  The dialogue is the starring role here, and what a performance it gives. Kevin Smith's script is incredibly, side-splitting, funny.  It is the best thing about the film.  Highly recommended, but some people may find it offensive.

This will be a very brief review of "Clerks." As the title of my review states, "Overrated Student Film." It's an OK student film, but it seems that its niche audience has glorified it into something it isn't.The film has mediocre acting by actors who are really only known for portraying characters in Kevin Smith films.The film wasn't shot in black and white because Smith was trying to give the film a certain noir look or because he was trying to be artsy. The film was shot in black and white film because it was cheaper than color film back in 1994. Today the film would be shot in color using a digital camera. "Clerks II" is definitely better than this film because it looks professionally done, and the acting is somewhat better, and "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back" is by far the best of the three films.If it weren't for "Clerks" we probably would never have heard of Kevin Smith, and heck he might have still been working at that store. Critics at the time seemed to have had the same fascination that they had for Diablo Cody when "Juno" came out. "Wow, she's a former stripper who wrote a screenplay." "Wow, Kevin Smith actually works at the Quick Stop,and made a movie." He is basically a comic book nerd who got extremely lucky because of this film, and his fellow comic book fan boys have catapulted this film into the stratosphere.

reviews.review_title: To my surprise, I found this to be work of art
reviews.content: After seeing `Clerks,' I am reminded of the feeling I had after seeing the classic `Un chien andalou' in my college cinema class many years ago. While Clerks, certainly, was nowhere near as expressionistic and surreal as the Bunuel-Dali classic, it certainly leaves one with a realization that one has just watched a well-constructed work of art on a bizarre and grotesque canvas.This was my first Kevin Smith production and I had no idea what to expect. I still had no idea what to expect until very late in the film. Reviewing Clerks is even more of a challenge because it is NOT the type of film I typically watch. This is being written by a reviewer who considers the original `12 Angry Men' one of Hollywood's greatest films and someone who looks back mournfully to the days when Hollywood still made family films.I would dare say that many who know me would assume I would hate this film, if I ever somehow wound up viewing it. I have to admit that the constant graphic language  especially in the early-going  grated on my nerves a bit. Still, this was a most original and inspired project.Tracing a day in the life of two convenience store clerks in the same black & white footage that the store's security camera might be shooting, might not sound particularly inspiring. Yet Smith packs some wonderful dialogue, lots of humor and irony and a sense of poignancy as we take a glimpse into the life of two young losers,  Dante Hicks (Brian O'Halloran) and Randal Graves (Jeff Anderson).SPOILERS AHEADThe film obviously is more than the sum of its parts and it is obviously making a deeper statement than `Boy hates job; boy plans to dump girl; boy is dissed on all day; boy meets old girl; old girl is hospitalized after seducing a corpse; boy loses both girls; boy closes up shop.' Dante is a loser with the potential to do something with his life  and perhaps with a latent desire to do so. Randal takes what life offers without complaint. At times the two are reminiscent of Wally Cleaver and Eddie Haskell. Randal constantly manages to talk the semi-conscientious Dante into doing things that go against his better judgment, like closing the store to play hockey on the roof and to go to a friend's wake (then getting them thrown out by accidentally knocking over the coffin!). He happily insults his own video customers, as well as Dante's, gets Dante fined and breaks up a romance for him. Yet in the end he turns philosopher  maybe just a tad too much so for the film's credibility, but who's counting?Dante, in turn, is a loveable loser who has trouble saying `no' to anyone  a customer advising other shoppers not to buy cigarettes; an old man who need to use the bathroom; his hockey teammates; and, of course, his ex-girlfriend. Both his current and former girlfriends, he discovers, as the movie progresses, have led much wilder love lives than he ever realized. Humiliation after humiliation is compounded, but he winds up shrugging each off.  In the end, it is not evident whether he has made up his mind to improve his lot  or again resigned himself to staying put.In the meantime, Smith's dialogue and rapid-fire cast of customers (many cast members playing more than one) lead to some hilarious moments. Although the dialogue is often vulgar and constantly profane, Smith nevertheless shows a master comedy writer's deft touch. O'Halloran and Anderson are outstanding in their roles and very believable.I'm not sure if I'm a Kevin Smith fan yet or not. I will definitely seek out at least one more Smith film, though. His effort in Clerks merits that. This is not so much an entertainment movie as it is an artistic statement. Those of us who complain about Hollywood cranking out inane sequel after sequel (indeed, now cloning entire COLLECTIONS of sequels for NEW series of sequels!) and teeny-bop junk with no depth, cannot simultaneously rip Clerks for its earthy tone, vulgarities and less than flattering look at the seamier side of today's drive-through society. For all its potential draw-backs, Clerks has one definite thing going for it. It is a work of art.

reviews.review_title: Do you have that one with that guy who was in that movie last year?
reviews.content: This is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen! The humor is subtle, vulgar, and witty all at once. Randal is the funniest, but Jay and Silent Bob also a crack-up. Clerks had a smaller budget than an expensive pair of Nike's, but you don't need money to be funny (no pun intended, because now that I read it it looks pretty gay). The movie is not only funny,but it has a point..... being a clerk sucks! Towards the end, however, there is a bit of truth, but i hate spoilers, so I won't say anything. #7 in my favorite movies. 9/10

This is by far one of the most interesting and funniest movies I have seen lately. The director Kevin Smith manages to keep the viewer glued to the screen, despite the fact that there is no substantial progress in the story as such. The script uses a lot of time to establish the characters, while maintaining the charm of the movie. The director has managed to keep the whole picture simple and realistic. The best bits are the parts of conversation between the two leads. Its no surprise to me that the movie caught up with the 'Cult' status instantaneously. The characters are exquisitely portrayed by all actors. It seemed like the actors are in real life like the characters they played, which made the acting seem so natural. Probably the reason why many of the characters are immortalized. Funny characters, simple script and cinematography blend with a some profanity in language is probable one of the most famous mantras to make a 'low-budget, high-rated cult classic'.

reviews.review_title: The best film by my favorite director
reviews.content: Out of all the writer/directors that I have seen films from, the one that sticks out the most for me is Kevin Smith.  I think he is the best filmmaker on the face of the Earth and he has five really funny and biting movies that to back up that title.  His best film IMO is "Clerks".  Although it is not my favorite movie of all time, it is in my Top Ten (#8 while Dogma is #9) and it is the best comedy I have ever seen.  "Clerks" takes dead aim at dead-end job sector with brutal honesty and almost unnerving satire.  Some of the topics that are explored in "Clerks" would probably make a dog gag but it helps to show what it is like to work in a job where the pay would qualify as slave wage and respect for the worker is nonexistent.  Even though all the characters are exaggerated to a certain degree, they are portrayed as real people who have feelings.  Because of the state of their lives and the hatred they have for their jobs, they take their frustrations out on the customers.  Since the movie is filmed in black and white, it gives you the perspective that you are watching a security camera video. The purpose of "Clerks" is to show what life is like as a person who works in the dead-end sector from day to day.  It makes for a very watchable and very likeable film.  Not to downplay great work by established kings like Lynch, The Coens, Soderbergh, Tarantino, Verhoeven, Gilliam and Curtis Hanson and relative newcomers like Shyamalan, Wes Anderson, Richard Kelly and Troy Duffy, Kevin Smith's work, for me, is the epitome of modern filmmaking.  "Clerks" should set the standard for all new comedies and even all new dramas that will be made in the coming years.  In short, "Clerks" will live on for generations to come and Kevin Smith will be remembered as one of the great filmmakers of all time.  I give all his movies 10 out of 10!PS:  Kevin Smith should have been nominated and won two Oscars for "Clerks". "Mallrats" shouldn't have been dissed by critics and moviegoers. "Chasing Amy" should have been in wider release.  "Dogma" should have been nominated for Best Picture at the 2000 Oscars.  "J&SBSB" should've been on every top ten list in 2001.Here ends my rant! :)

ok....a lot of people love this movie!  my friend said this was his favorite movie of all time.  i like black and white, i like movies that don't fit the norm....but this movie was so boring, i had to question my friend's taste. but, also, i know that when someone says how great a movie is, and you watch it thinking its gonna be better then anything you've seen before, 99% of the time, the movie will NOT live up to the expectations.  i don't like this movie at the present moment (of course i hated mallrats the first time i saw it but i love it now), but i am sure that in a few years i will watch it again and like it. so i recomend it, just shut up about it and let other decide.  DO NOT HYPE THIS ONE UP, OR YOU'LL RUIN IT!!

Smart, funny, good-hearted (who'da thought a guy would get good romantic advise from a couple of drug dealers), and nice.  Personally I like the ending they did (it would have ended on a REAL downer and sadly, perhaps proved Dante's Empire theory right).  Anyway this is a great debut from an under-appreciated writer, director and comic writer (he writes the comics Jay and Silent Bob, Clerks and did a kick ass run on Marvel's Daredevil.  It may have loose ends but that's part of the fun.  Don't miss the Deathstar conversation.

reviews.review_title: The Movie and the TV Sitcom Meet
reviews.content:
Kevin Smith, director and writer of Clerks, hit upon a great idea in 1994. A network TV sitcom does not require fancy camera angles, great sets or special effects. In the sitcom the camera mostly stays put while the actors do their thing. What a great discovery for an independent film maker because this "TV" style could obviously be used to make very low budget movie. Smith then uses an obvious advantage that film has over network TV. Movie comedy can be much more biting and raunchy. This is the setup for Clerks, R rated comedy in a TV sitcom style but it presents a big problem. Network TV comedies are designed to run in 10 minute segments broken by 5 minute commercial breaks and usually last for 30 minutes. Longer than 30 minutes and a TV comedy can quickly become very boring with the static camera angles and small sets. So how did Kevin Smith solve this problem?He does it very well because overall Clerks is terrific. Everything here depends on the script and Smith delivers a great one. To avoid a too static feel, Clerks is divided into small segments that are titled like separate episodes. But more importantly is Smith's comic timing. The jokes in Clerks build with one punch line after another reaching the right climax. On top of this the humor is often off the wall which feels fresh. While there are plenty of laughs here, I smiled throughout the entire film because I liked many of these characters and the goofy situations they are put in. This was also because I began to care about our "heros", Dante Hicks as the put upon hapless "responsible employee" and Randal Graves as his slacker sidekick. You can add a whole crowd of oddball supporting cast members who create "local color" to my list of why I really enjoyed Clerks. Being in black and white worked because this gave a convenience store harsh neon light look. The soundtrack is good and fits right in. Kevin Smith adds a twist to the plot that is unexpected. What is the relationship between Dante and Randal? Does Randal have a crush on him? It is only touched upon but it adds a little depth to the fun. (Such questions are more fully explored in another Kevin Smith film, Chasing Amy.)
I have only one slight quibble. Clerks rolls along staggering from one laugh to another but it does not seem to know how to end. I wasn't too disappointed because Clerks is a slice of life type of story and life is not neatly tied together in a bow. If you looking for a clever, gritty comedy, Clerks will deliver.

Cult Cuts Volume 7Clerks (1994)(8/10):Just a feel good comedy about life and growing up,but also Film Culture.Clerks follows a group of twenty somethings who either work at the local corner store or video store and how they live their lives just getting by,tolerating customers and all their relationship quarrels.Directed by Kevin Smith, who is just a cult film director in general now, this was essentially the 90s; the attitude,style and the video store culture became watered down and streamlined,it was a place where you can forge memories,friendships and maybe rent a movie or two and discover a new favourite,it was personal and Clerks manages to capture the essence of it all without sacrificing its authenticity or story.First off the Dry Humour was not really my kind of thing but I really enjoyed what Kevin was going for,he wanted them to feel like they knew each other well and they were essentially poking fun at one another.Secondly the Soundtrack is by far probably one of the best the 90s has to offer.The humour is also very raunchy and dirty at times;I mean it is focused on these young adults in a movie store.The visual style is also very different than any other comedy I've seen,a black and white film grain,I know it was an independent film but was that an artistic choice or just a limitation he had at the time?Also I don't understand the title cards,the moments where it cuts to black with one word in the middle that usually a human emotion,that was different.However my issues aside,It's just super easygoing and pretty hard not to like.It is also very difficult not to enjoy it as a cinephile as it represents a bygone era of film and the more personal experience that a video store offers that I can only think of one other that does so,being Be-Kind Rewind,but this is just wholly a better film.

The '1990's gave us some real bad music. Nirvana, Pearl Jam, boy bands. The 90's did have one redeeming value. The movies. Clerks is one of them. Shoestring budget, Kevin Smith mortgaged his life to make this film. in fact, almost as much was spent on the three minute Soul Asylum video then was spent on Clerks. I laughed so hard at Clerks, i lost breath twice. I've worked retail. Dante and more so Randal say almost everything that a retail clerk would want to say. They get away with it as well. Kevin Smith proved himself a genius. Raunchy humor, endless sight gags, and the best use of a small cast i've ever seen. Something to offend everyone, and that's what makes this room so great. Another thing that makes so film so great was that it spawned sequels without them being true sequels. It was a series of movies that all tied in with each other. Even having the same actors play other roles. Not something that main stream Hollywood had done. Clerks made Hollywood take notice, and for awhile, they stayed away from the cookie cutter approach to making movies. No movie as important as Clerks had been made in a great while. If you haven't seen clerks, you don't know what you're missing. Best movie of the 90's. enough said.

reviews.review_title: I'm the only one in America
reviews.content: I'm the only one in America who hated this film... I don't know maybe I'm a fan of good acting and maybe the jokes in the movie would have been funny if they were presented the right way??? but I just couldn't get into this film the acting in it was horrible I blame it on the acting because I don't want to blame Kevin Smith for his direction. The only Kevin Smith movie I liked was Chasing Amy and I feel the acting had a lot to do with it. I really need to give this movie a 2nd chance because everyone I've ever talked to LOVES this movie.

reviews.review_title: Are there any balls down there?
reviews.content: Clerks is a rare thing indeed a low budget (about $25,000) indie comedy that's actually funny, not in an intellectual gentle way i.e. Garden State but in a gut wrenching laugh out loud way. Made with amateur actors in many roles performances are pretty good although the odd line is fluffed this only adds to its charm. The plot is difficult to explain as its just about two guys in a convenience store and one weird day, the script is sharp with plenty of humour but clearly has something to say no matter how muddled. Jay & Silent Bob make their first appearance here but its Randall and supporting characters that have the best lines. The best way to describe this film is a slacker comedy it's perfect to watch with your mates and pizza. The only negatives I can think of are the film is a bit rough but c'mon what do you expect for 25k and anyone adverse to bad language should avoid this!! Rough, rude, ridiculous and seriously funny 8/10

I'd heard so much about 'Clerks' that maybe it was inevitable that I was disappointed by it.  I know, it was shot for next to nothing, but how much of the film does that excuse? In my opinion, the weakest part of the movie was not the production value or acting (although they do feel as cheap as they are), but the screenplay.  Given there are several funny bits in the film, overall it's a mess.  It really goes nowhere and takes too long to get there.My guess is that if this film were made today, nobody'd ever hear about it. 'Clerks' came about at just the right time, on the cusp of new indie popularity.  Maybe this film was responsible for some of it.  In that respect, I appreciate this movie.  In most others, I don't.

...Regardless to what some people may say, this is a great film, even more so due to the story of Kevin Smith's efforts to make this movie. I am a student film maker and I consider "Clerks." to be the biggest influence on me, because this film proves to anyone with the desire to make movies that they can do it!The dialogue is the strongest the thing about Clerks. Kevin Smith really can write a good script as he has proven since making Clerks.And if we were all being honest we'd agree that the acting is pretty damn poor... but what the hell do you expect?For what it is 9/10

Kevin Smith is a true genius. While maybe not for all viewers, Clerks is one of his best (along with Dogma). This movie is very funny if your sense of humour allows it to be. A perfect ten without a doubt. Jay & Silent Bob in their prime.

reviews.review_title: A classic start for Kevin and crew
reviews.content: Kevin Smith made a film about how it's hard working long hours, and having to deal with a lot of characters Dante: A hopeless worker who just wants to get out of his dead end job and live his life the way he wants. He gets the call from his boss to come in on his day off and right away huge runs into trouble. "Someone jammed gum in the locks", customers come in almost every minute.Randal: Dante's best friend is New Jersey's top pop culture junkie and a smart Alick. He does all he can to cheer Dante up while annoying the customers in every way shape or form. His job is at the video store right next to the Quick Stop. OK now is the time as come to mention that this film is the introduction to two have my movie heroes Jay and Silent Bob. Jay: a fast foul mouth dude that just hangs out with his muted parter in front of the stores selling. Those are the four main characters shown in B&W that made comedy history. Yes its a comedy I promise you will laugh and enjoy two thumbs up Mr. Smith

reviews.review_title: The most true to life movie I've ever seen.
reviews.content: I know a couple of people who are convenience store clerks and are absolutely miserable working there.People like Dante Hicks who works at a lowly convenience store the Quick Stop in New Jersey. He's not even supposed to be there today. He has problems with his best friend Randal Graves who mans RST Video next door, conflicts with two of his loves, a loss of an old girlfriend, a hockey game and he smells like shoe polish. All of this revolves around his day at work.This movie is great! I like Chasing Amy and Mallrats better but this film is just as fun as the two of them. Bottom line: Great film, great fun. 10/10

Clerks is one of the best independent movies I have ever seen.  For the longest time I heard about Kevin Smith and his connecting movies.  Years ago I came across it on Cinna-max and just had to check it out.  Wow.  You don't even notice the black & white after a while.  It was funny, edgy, and true. 
This movie is primarily about Dante Hicks who is a "Clerk" in a Convenience store.  He is in his early 20's and doesn't plan on going to college.  He likes life the way it is, simple.  Although as you will see, life is far from simple for Dante Hicks.  The basic idea of the movie is Dante is called in to work on his day off. He agrees to come in because he is under the impression its for a little bit, but is dead wrong.  Nothing can go right on this day.  He gets company from his good friend Randal Graves who is the complete opposite from him. Dante is nice, kind, and cares about what people think.  Randal has no respect for anyone and you will laugh out loud, at his lack of respect throughout the movie.This movie is a Cult Classic and is a must see.  It was only made for $25K+. Yet it does a great job and you have to see the other Kevin Smith movies to see the connections they all have with one another.

reviews.review_title: I'm glad I found this one
reviews.content: Clerks is, in my opinion, the best indie movie I have or will ever see. A lot of people, including myself, can totally relate to this. It makes fun of how customers are complete idiots, as well as co-workers in some cases, it makes fun of gossip, and other stuff in our day-to-day life. The fact that in the beginning Dante gets called into work on his day off, while his manager is nowhere to be found, shows the true fact that a lot of managers treat their employees like crap. The conversations between Dante and his pal Randall are really hilarious, and this film provides the film debut of the best duo since Batman & Robin, Jay and Silent Bob, who grace the screen inbetween scenes (the scene where they dance is great). For those who complain that the acting was bad, it's because THEY'RE NOT ACTORS! And other people where complaining that there was no plot, it's the day in the life of a store clerk, what the heck where you expecting, Die Hard 4? For anyone with a sense of humor, and half a brain, rent and enjoy this low budget, homemade, work of art.

Most people in this world don't like their jobs and I'm sure that convenience store employees don't like all their customers. This movie is absolutely hilarious and at some times a little exaggerated (like spitting on a customer) but all in all this is a classic movie and probably one of the cheapest movies ever made. Kevin Smith apparently had a $25,000 budget for this film. Go figure why it's in black and white. I love all Kevin Smith movies but this one is definitely up there as one of his best next to "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back" but Jay and Silent Bob wouldn't have existed without "Clerks" and that's why this is Kevin Smith's best movie.

reviews.review_title: Simply the best comedy film ever!
reviews.content: Ok, this amazingly excellent movie is about a couple of guys who are fed up with not having fun while they work.  So they become completely rebellious. But everything gets back to normal again.Rated R for strong language.

This low-budget masterpiece is about as good as they come.  The first of director Kevin Smith's New Jersey films is one of the best as it follows a day in the life of a clerk at a convenience store.  Often hilarious, and thoughtful at the same time, this is what I wish big-budget Hollywood productions could live up to.  The film is a lot of fun and features the cinematic debut of Jay and Silent Bob, the pot-smoking duo who steals the show in every one of the Smith films.  Mallrats is the next movie in the series, and if you want to see some funny, enjoyable films,  the Kevin Smith movies are as good a place as any to start.  My highest recommendation.

It just shows that you don't need a big Hollywood budget to create a magnificent work of art. The dark, sarcastic humor highlights this film as our tragic hero, Dante, has a series of defining events that help shape his perspective of his own future with the help of goof-ball friend, Randal. It entwines the intellectual genius of director/writer Kevin Smith with comedy and drama. Frankly it's a gem and easily one of the best movies made in the last 20 years.Some may view it as a quasi-documentary as it delves deep into the life of an actual store clerk. While some "incidences" are taken out of proportion for the audience's enjoyment, there is a layer of realism without being too forced or scripted. Overall 3.5/4 stars, 8/10

Clerks is agonizingly pretentious and unfunny and the acting is terrible to boot. If Kevin Smith shaved his beard and threw away his baseball cap he would disappear from the pop-culture landscape; and that would be a good thing.

reviews.review_title: Gritty black humor and honest human interaction
reviews.content: I watched the first cut version of "Clerks." I was prepared to be mildly amused and not much impressed. I ended up enthralled, deeply moved, and with a ton of admiration for Kevin Smith's direction. I tend to like low-budget movies more than polished, expensive ones, in part because my tastes are classical, and simplicity attracts me. I also admire the inventiveness needed to make a good film with simple means and not much money.This film, for me, succeeds 100% in meeting those goals. Yes, there are moments, several of them, that are contrived, but there is no indication, from the first scene, that the film is intended to be naturalistic. The director later had misgivings about Dante falling out of a closet, presumably because he had to sleep there due to the dog taking up the bed. I think it was a stroke of genius, for it "warns" the viewer that strange things are apt to happen in the film. They certainly do--abundantly.SPOILER FOLLOWS:When it came to the last scene, I had a sudden sense of foreboding, and then came the awful ending to the film. I felt shattered and yet I felt that this was exactly right--in keeping with what city life really is. Is it still a comedy? Yes and no. I will be reflecting on the contrast between the body of the film and its horrific ending for a long time, and don't expect to find any easy answers.The friendship between Randal and Dante, who can neither stand each other nor do without each other, is so well portrayed with such simple means that I marvel at the psychological perception required, and used. Randal really is a guy who genuinely wants to help others, and this is slowly revealed through the film. He's clumsy, he's rude, he can be obscene, but he basically has compassion that wins out. I think this is one of the best characterizations I've seen anywhere.I rated this a ten. Before I watched it, I figured it would deserve maybe a four, from what I'd heard of it. I will be watching this one again.

Kevin Smith debut is a foul mouthed slacker comedy without any real plot, an abundance of childish humour and endless monologues about pop culture that cannot fail to charm the pants off you.
Dante hicks is called in to work at quickstop groceries on his day off and spends the day with his bwst friend randall who works in the video rental shop next door slacking off and dealing with an array of off beat customers including the now infamous jay and silent Bob.
Smith is a master wordsmith and he he will have you howling with laughter through out clerks and then towards the end as always he'll show you the heart he and all his moves were proudly on the sleaves leaving you feeling with a nice warm fuzz and utterly charmed feeling.
A must see.

reviews.review_title: Welcome to the world of Kevin Smith
reviews.content: I love Clerks. I love how whiny Dante is, and I love how Randal cares about no one and nothing. This is the introduction to the world of Kevin Smith. Clerks is the first movie of five (the other four go in order: Mallrats, Chasing Amy, Dogma, and Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back) and fixates itself around Quick Stop store clerk Dante having to go in on his day off. This proves to be one of the worst days of his life. Things start off with a cigarette revolt and don't get any better from there. I like how Kevin Smith makes the movie around one big line repeated by Dante: "I'm not even supposed to be here today!" It's just cool to see how one persons life can be ripped to pieces when: your boss lies to you, your ex-girlfriend is "getting married" your best friend shows up late for work as usual, and you have to come in on your day off, among an array of other things I don't want to spoil. Clerks is filled with witty humor and memorable characters and great dialouge. If you like this movie you're bound to become a fan of Kevin Smith's work. Especially Jay and Silent Bob.

reviews.review_title: Good comedy about life in the grocery trade
reviews.content: Clerks (pronounced Clarks) is an old American film that had been lost in the archives for decades. The story goes that when written it was so rude that no distributer dared release it. Fast forward 50 years and we find young American slacker Kelvin Smith who works as a cleaner in movie studios. He accidentally fell into one of the cabinets which contains all Hollywood's movie reels which revealed a secret hole in the wall. Looking inside Smith found the long lost Clerks movie and stole it. After watching it he realised he could become a fat millionaire if he released it- it was the nineties and this was just the sort of comedy that people flocked to see. Being an amateur filmmaker himself he spliced in a couple of scenes starring himself and adding a couple of his favourite songs to the track. Taking his movie to Caines (the Southern French town owned by Michael who runs a yearly film festival there) he hoped his movie would be successful. Low down and behold, he was right! Clerks kick started a new wave of funnies, where people talked about their favourite movies and comics with toilet metaphors and sexy treats thrown in.Clerks (pronounced Clirks) is about 2 friends who work in a shop in Kansas. One works in a Video shop, the other in a greengrocers, but both just sit about bored all day and make fun of the customers as they have a higher intellect. Observe the following exchange: Customer: Excuse me, can I buy this milk? Randy (sighs and tuts): Uh! You f*cking idiot! Of course you CAN buy this milk as long as you have tree fiddy. You should be asking MAY I buy this milk. You are an imbecile. Customer: F*ck you! Randy: Oh wow! You must have a Shakespearean grasp of the English language and a huge brain to have thought up such a witty and well developed response. (Customer walks away) Randy: Yeah! Yo Momma!Between customers they climb onto the top of the shop and play an American version of the English game Chess, known as Roof Hockey. Occasionally they argue about their favourite films: Randy: Which did you like better- Police Acad3my 3 or Police Academy 4? Dainty: 3 Randy: You blaspheme! Dainty: Nein! 3 Was when Zedd finally joined the good guys, he screamed at the door and made it fall down, all the other recruits were training again to further their policing skills, and Mauser was much better than Harris. Randy: Idiotte! 4 had tones of great new recruits, hot air balloons, yumma yumma yumma yumma YUM-MA! And Tony Hawk. All 3 had was a bunch of Muppets.So goes their lives. The film is a series of loosely connected skits either dialogue or slapstick based, all revolving around brown jokes. My main problem is that the film is too American. I didn't really get most of the obscure movie references and a lot of the words used are foreign to me. A lot of the time I don't understand the accent and it is made worse by the fact that it is black and white. The film therefore is clearly very old and out of touch with today's language and society. I did enjoy a couple of parts, like when the wench goes into the traps and Spacs up an oul chump, getting a mouth gift in the wrong place. Broxn!Best Scene: When the popular comedy due Joe and Salient Burt are dancing outside; that one scene explained more to me about America in the 1940s than any text book ever did.

I love this film, for many reasons on many levels. Kevin Smith, the director and writer of this film has realized a vision, broken down walls and demystified the filmmaking process all in the act of making an entertaining film that just happens to be a low-budget, money-making miracle.The film is shot in black and white. OK, so this is going to turn off the kind of people who actually LIKE the colourization of old films, which to film lovers like myself is tantamount to updating the clothes on the Mona Lisa with a halter top or putting a Bic lighter in the Statue of Liberty's hand.The language is at times offensive. Alright, I'll give you that, it doesn't bother me particularly, and doesn't seem excessive given the characters and the situation. Certainly no more cursing than can be found in "Pulp Fiction", yet everyone calls attention to the violence in that film, a lesser of two evils sort of thing. But you probably don't want to have this film playing with kids running around.The film is a first effort, and the actors are not the greatest in the world. The script is tight and obviously born out of experience as it's elements are convincingly realistic, and if nothing else, proves that even from a mundane job like a variety store clerk, you can achieve your dreams if you have the courage and desire to make them come true. Kevin followed up these films with what is often referred to as the "New Jersey Trilogy" among his fans, with "Mallrats" and "Chasing Amy". I enjoyed these films to varying degrees, but still find "Clerks" more inspired and entertaining than even the hit "Chasing Amy", which by all accounts displays the improved techniques of a more mature filmmaker.

This movie is one of the best Kevin Smith movies that i've EVER seen, i know that there are the usual complaints that "its in black and white!" but to be honest, you have to see past that and you will see a movie that is incredible in every shape and form!The characters etc. in this movie are some of the best that i've ever seen, Dante esp. I felt soo sorry for him at times! It was awful to see the crap that he went thru and as he sez so often "i'm not even meant to be here today!" and Randle is just a lil' *$%* if i've ever seen one! He's very funny don't get me wrong but God! I couldn't do with him being a friend!
Watch this movie before you watch any of Kevin Smiths other stuff and see what you think of it, i watched this like 3rd in the series and i was lucky that i liked it, not many people do, but i think that this deserves to be in the best 250 voting statistics! This movie is jut plain awesome!

reviews.review_title: a comparatively weak but essential part of the kevin smith collection.
reviews.content: it is the weakest of the famous (infamous?) jersey series by kevin smith, but by no means a weak film. put out by mirimax, THE new-hollywood/inde company that brought independant films to hollywood and pollished the genre up for the rest of pop-culture to ingest, clerks is rough, single camera, and dialogue impacted. done in b/w (for lack of budget or by ingeniuos design) it gives the feeling of being a voyer through the "security" cameras of life.excellent. to get the full effect of the jersey series, see these films in order. they link together beautifully.

reviews.review_title: Youthful movie is fun for adults too
reviews.content: Some of the humor is the toilet variety and the movie is most appealing to young males but I and my mature companion both cracked up at some of the lines and scenarios that got tossed into the movies' mix. I think you would be a little fossilized not to laugh at the jokes. The old man with peculiar restroom requests and sex with a dead man were particularly funny. Think of the crappy expensive comedies you've seen and you'll appreciate this budget movie gem. I gave it an 8.

Clerks is a funny movie that satirizes the routine life of everyone who has to work for another. It is witty, cleverly written and well directed.
I believe that the key to the film's success is the way it appeals to the viewer : everyone knows a Dante and most of us have experienced difficult situations like some of which Dante goes through in the movie! Yet, in my opinion, what the director tried to accomplish (successfully, I may add) is not a realistic depiction of the everyday life of a working man, but rather a SURrealistic approach to the repetitive reality of the common man, which can be tragic, hilarious, or some of both. The fact that the main character feels constantly oppressed by the people surrounding him and by the environment where he works is not emphasized throughout the movie pointlessly; the message that the director wants to get through to us is that no matter how sucked in we are by routine, we still have the potential to change the way we live. And the means the director uses in order to get through to us is comedy. Clerks is a film of high value. Watch it with friends; it will bring up various issues to discuss later... My only objection is O'Halloran; I've seen amateurs acting way better than him!8

I watched Clerks a few days ago, for the first time. For the first time in my life, have I fully understood a movie, after watching this. The story is about Dante a guy who works at a convenience store and his friend Randal who works at a movie rental store next door, and their dislike for customer.I can relate to this film since I worked in a grocery store as a meat cutter for about 2 and half years. While it's not the same as working in a convenience store, I still had to deal with people face to face. There were a lot of customers who I disliked with a passion, because they treated me like a 2nd class citizen at various times. Now doing customer support over the phone, it is still a pain because people still treat me poorly and do not listen to what I have to tell them, because they feel they are better than me.This a great film to watch. The film was made in black and white, which even if it was done in color would have not made a difference. This film has some of the best lines that I have ever heard in a movie, and this is very low budget. The acting is stellar, and is some of the best acting that I have ever heard. There is also some very funny lines and some ones that are just plain genius. Slient Bob only has one line in this film, but it was the best line ever "You know, there's a million fine looking women in the world, dude. But they don't all bring you lasagna at work. Most of 'em just cheat on you." I will say though that this film is not for everyone. If you don't like profanity, than stay away from this film, because it is full of it. If you don't like hearing about porn then stay away from this film. If you never worked a customer service job, or have never had a job before than don't watch this film, you will not understand it. This film is a great film to watch, and if you ever had worked a customer service based job, if it be a job a convenience store, or doing customer support over a phone, you must watch this film. I can tell you that you will related to it.

reviews.review_title: Probably the greatest independent film ever made
reviews.content: Clerks is the biggest reason I wanted to get into film. What makes this film so great is that Kevin Smith captures the class struggle and gives a critique of capitalism. Also, the writing is extremely clever and hilarious. The characters are written so realistically. This'll always be one of the most quotable films ever.

Forget Daniel Day Lewis. Walter Flanagan delivers a tour de force performance across multiple roles. Without Walt Flanagan's masterful acting abilities, Clerks would have tanked and no one would know Kevin Smith's name.

Couldn't watch the film until I myself escaped the servitude of standing behind a register. This flick said it all for the average person who was chained to a register. Counting each year their soul and youth was devoured. Each scene perfectly depicts this pain in a wonderfully comical manner. For those of you unfamiliar with this show I highly recommend "Clerks X" complete with the original directors cut for a more rewarding experience. The alternate ending says it all. Moving forward for most folks stuck in this profession is a pipe dream. If anyone has had a need of added incentive for finding a better profession then get them a copy of this flick fast. In this movie comedy has a noble cause. Thank you View Askew. Watch and enjoy.

Keven Smith dares to be different in this little flick about many things called "Clerks". It's shot on film in grainy black and white and rotates around several friends and some enemy's circulating around a corner store. I love this movie, its crude, rude and even though nobody gets fully nude it almost got an NC-17 rating! Well it didn't and what you have here is a fiercely original one time flash in the pan, culminating what probably millions of people do on a daily basis (or did at one point) Rent Movies. I don't know if seeing less color, i.e. just seeing black and white helps tie down complex stories but i love it's simplicity. This is probably Kevin Smith's best work i don't think anything he did after came close to the genius of this movie. It's slightly offbeat and will continue to posses a strange charm. Ten bloody stars.

reviews.review_title: Just because I comment on it, doesn't mean I like it
reviews.content: I mean I love it, but It doesn't necessarily mean that. I cannot put into words how funny I feel this movie is. Well, that is actually a lie, because I can. Its witty, arodite (sp?), hysterical, urbane, but mostly it is just good comedy about someone having sex with a dead guy. Yes, other things happen in the movie, but really are they at all important. I have watched this movie 20+ times, and while it is not perfect it is much better than alot of what has come before. Oh and Kevin Smith right now, has a really fat butt. I mean, dude needs to go on slim fast. I really am only saying that for a few reasons. 1) its true. 2)to prove that I don't worship Mr. Smith like I used to. 3)so you guys can appreciate his (relative) slimness in this movie.

reviews.review_title: makes you wanna be a clerk ... for a day
reviews.content:
I wanted to see "Dogma" before I decide, which movie I gonna comment on. Both movies were fine, but I liked "Clerks" better. As the title suggests this movie is about a day in the life of two, convenience and video store, clerks. For the money it was made $27 000, this movie was a very original, creative and interesting one. The witted dialogues between the two friends (clerks) are in the center of the movie, however my favorite moment is the Dante's girlfriend confession about her previous obsession for fellatio. Despite of the somewhat wooden performance by some of the cast, the overall feeling of warmth and humanity from the screen stayed intact.  This movie comes to say that we can find something interesting in everybody's lives. That's why those "Candid Camera," "Real TV" or "Cops" shows are popular. A mean, the clerks' life obviously could be interesting. Life is an interesting thing; it is just that we have to find that thing.
P.S. The black and white thing was something I couldn't understand the meaning of; I think in color this movie would've looked so much more ... colorful.

This independent low-budget movie makes you laugh out loud more than most of Hollywood's big studios movies. It is amazing how original and hilarious this movie is.Kevin Smith is a genius .. the secret behind this great movie is the good script that is loaded with good & funny lines.Brian O'Halloran , Jeff Anderson & Marilyn Ghigliotti were good .. Kevin Smith as Silent Bob is fine. The conversations are funny .. no matter what subjects it includes & how long it takes.One thing maybe was missing in the movie .. music .. it is not necessary in some kind of movies but I'd like more if there's a nice piece or two in the movie.Simply amazing movie .. I can't wait until I see the sequel.

reviews.review_title: The debut film from Kevin Smith!
reviews.content:
"Clerks" was written and directed by first-timer Kevin Smith.  To tell you the truth, I found this movie very funny!  I couldn't stop laughing.  There were many good things with this movie, including the debut of potheads Jay & Silent Bob.  It was filmed in Black & White.  And it was very cool.  Plus, this movie had alot of sick jokes, but, they were so cool.  Kevin Smith is a god!  If you've seen all of Kevin's films instead of "Clerks," then check this out!
A *****1/2 (out of ****** stars)

reviews.review_title: Movie shows you don't need a big budget to make a movie.
reviews.content: I decided to check out Clerks one day and I was not disappointed this movie is simply amazing everything about it is perfect. The characters are funny and memorable and each person is unique in their own way I love the indie style of the film because the budget was $27,575 and they had to use black and white cameras but they did such a good job on using their limited resources and proves that you don't need millions of dollars to create a film, also some scenes can maybe relate to people who have or had worked at a movie or convenience store overall its hands down one of the best films I've ever seen it may be in black and white but it will still make you laugh.

Kevin Smith molds a curiously clever and smart film using no budget, no big names, and writing it himself. Fast, witty dialogue is everywhere throughout. He is a master at spoofing the pop culture and clearly shows it with his obviously high-intellectual writing abilities. One of the ultimate slacker comedies.  9/10

Many people who talk about Kevin Smith's movies say that "Clerks" is the best movie out of the library.  I really beg to differ.  Perhaps it was the first bit of Kevin Smith that they saw, which lends to nostalgia.  Looking in retrospect, "Clerks" suffers quite badly due to mediocre to complete amateur acting. The timing is a little bit off.   Some jokes seem to fall flat, if at all intended to be funny.In comparison, Smith's "Mallrats" and "Dogma" are laugh-a-thons that also have wit.    Chasing Amy has humour and heart.  Clerks doesn't give too good of a message, and its unclear to me if it even has a plot!As a first film, it's a good effort, but has no comparison to his other features.

Clerks is a perfect example of what you can accomplish with no budget but a whole lot of talent.The fact it was shot on 16 mm and looks like a documentary adds a whole voyeuristic feel to it that I think aids it greatly...a more polished Hollywood production probably would have had a lesser effect.What makes this movie stand out is the sheer talent of everyone involved. The script is excellent, managing to be outrageously funny at times yet dead serious at others. This movie will make you laugh your ass off then make you ponder things like the meaning of life and the age old question of "Where do I belong on this Earth?" The dialogue is from heaven...it's witty and intelligent to the point you can never be bored no matter how long two characters just sit around and talk. It takes a lot of talent to be able to hold an audience's interest on the screen while two characters just chat for 3 to 4 minutes while doing nothing. You will never be bored. The acting is also great because it's just so natural-looking...everyone here gives a performance that makes you believe they really are these people. It doesn't feel like acting.This may not be the best movie ever made and it's certainly an acquired taste...some will ever love or hate it, but it is a damn fine example of what can be accomplished when you have lots of talent yet no money. For me the movie rang true to life and managed to keep me solidly entertained for an hour and a half, so I have no problem with that!
